preguntáras por una baſquiña, una ſáya entera, una ropa, un manto, o un cuerpo, una gorguéra, de una toca, y coſas ſemejantes, ſupiéra te yo reſpondér.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p:
In that which belongeth vnto me, if
thou hadſt asked of a peticoate, a womans caſſocke, a womans gowne a mantell, a paire of bodies, a gorget, or a womans head attire, and like matters, I could haue anſwered thee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: De manera que no ſabe léer, mas de por el libro de ſu aldéa.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: So then the priest cannot ſay maſſe but in his owne booke.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Quieres tu, que ſea yo, como el ymbidióſo, que ſu cuidado es en lo que no le va ni le viéne.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Wilt thou, that I ſhould be as the enuious perſon which ſetteth his minde on that which belongs not vnto him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Siempre es virtúd ſavér, aunque ſean cóſas que pareçe que no nos ympórtan.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yet alwaies it is a vertue to know, although they be things which ſeem not to appertaine vnto vs.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Bien ſé yo, que tu ſabrás hazér una bellaquería, y éſta no es virtúd.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I know well, that thou knowest well how to play the knaue, and that I am ſure is no vertue.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: El ſavérla hazér no es malo, el uſárla ſi.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To know how to doe it is not euill, but to vſe it it is euill.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: ❀ Siempre oy dezír que quien las ſábe las táñe.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I alwaies haue heard ſay, he that can play, plaieth.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: ❀ No ſino que quien ha las he chas ha las ſoſpéchas.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No but whoſoeuer is bad, hath ſuſpition of another to be bad.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Pues velláco que he hecho yo?

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Why knaue what haue I done?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No mas de hazérme regañái algunas vézes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Nothing elſe, but make me fret and vexe my ſelfe ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p: No me des tu ocaſión.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Doe not thou giue me occaſion?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Eſtonces muchas merçédes, quando le doy ocaſion, es meneſtér que me perdóne, que quando no ſe la doy, poca amiſtád me haze.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Then I thanke you hartily, when I giue you occaſion it is neceſſarie that you pardon me, that when I giue you no occaſion, you doe mee littleMeaning then ſhe doth not forgiue him any thing, ſeeing he maketh no offence vnto her. curteſie.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p: A ora hermáno dexate de retóricas y has lo que tu ámo te mandó.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Now brother, leaue your rhetoricke, and doe that thy M. commanded thee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Si haré aun que bien créo que no por éſſo me tengo de aſentár con el ala meſa.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: So will I doe, although I beleeue, for all that I am not to ſit at table with him.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p: A lomenos eſcuſarás de que el no te aſiénte en el rábo.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Thou must needes beare with that, for that he doth not ſet it on your bum.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yo voy a enſillár el cavállo, a dios paredes haſta la buelta.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I goe to ſaddle the horſe, farewell wals till my returne.

row.cell: Diálogo ſegúndo, en el qual, ſe tráta de compràr y vendér jóyas y otras coſas entre un Hidálgo llamado Thomas, y ſu mugér Margaríta, y un Mercadér y un Platéro.
The ſecond Dialogue, wherin is handled to buie and ſell iewels and other things, betweene a gentleman called Thomas and his wife Margaret, and a Merchant, and a goldſmith.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: A Donde queréis que vamos Señóra?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: WHither will you that wee goe Ladie?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Vámos a la platería, y comprarémos algunas piéças de plata.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Let vs go to the goldſmithes ſhops, and we will buie ſome peeces of plate.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Y de alli?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: And from thence whither?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Yrémos a la lonja para comprár algunas cóſas.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: We will go to the Exchange to buy ſom things.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: En el nombre de Dios, entrémos en éſta tiénda.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: In the name of God let vs go into this ſhop.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Plegue a el, ſea con pie derecho.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I praie God it be in good time, luckely.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: A Señor guarde Dios a v.m.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Oh maſter goldſmith, God ſaue you.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Y venga con vuéſtras merçédes.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: And God be in your companie.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Mande nos moſtrár, algunas buénas piéças.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Cauſe one to ſhew vs ſome good peeces.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Que géneros quiere v.m. táças, copas o jarros, fuentes, platos, y eſcudillas, es lo mas neceſsário.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: What kinds will your worſhips ſee, plain cups, deep cups, or pots, ewers, platters, or diſhes, all theſe are the most neceſſarie.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Y tanbien copas de ſalvo, y ſaléros, vinagéras.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: And alſo cups with couers, and ſaltſellers, and bottles for vineger and oyle.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Ola móço, ſaca aqui toda eſſa plata de el arca.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Ho ſirra, take out heere all this plate out of this cheſt.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Veamos aquellos candeléros y deſpaviladéras.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Let vs ſee theſe candleſtickes and ſnuffers.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Si eſtos braſerillos de méſa eſtuviéran Sinceládos fuéran mejóres.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: If thoſe chafindiſhes for the table were engrauen they were better.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Otros dízen, que la ſinceladúra es allegadéro de miérda, hablando con perdón de vueſtras merçédes.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Others ſay, that the grauing is a gathering of filth, ſpeaking with reuerence of your worſhips.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: No véo aquí agua maníl ningúno.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I ſee no baſen here.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Aqui eſtá vno ſobre dorádo y ſinçeládo con ſu fuente de la miſma labór.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Here is one gilt ouer, and graued with his ewer of the ſame worke.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Yo quiſiéra toda la baxilla de una miſma labór que no diferençiáran vnas pieças de otras.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: I would haue all a cupboord of plate all of one worke, that there might not differ one peece from another.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Por eſſo dízen, que tantas opiniónes ay como cabeças: otros dízen que la variedád es la que agráda.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Therefore they ſay, ſo many men ſo many mindes, others ſay varietie breedes delight.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Es verdád, peró la variedád ha de ſer de coſas entéras, y por que hazér vna capa de remiéndos, no puede agradár a nádie.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: It is true, but that varietie is to be of whole entire things by themſelues, for to make a cloake with patches can pleaſe no bodie.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Conçierte ſe v.m. conmígo en el préçio, que yo ſe la daré acabáda dentro de pocas días de la hechura que la quiſiére.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Agree with me for the price, and I wil make it vp for you within theſe few daies, of what faſhion you will haue it.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Siempre en las tardanças ay pelígro, y vale mas páxaro en mano que bueytre bolándo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Alwaies delaies breede danger, and better a birde in hand then a vulture flying.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Pues eſcoja de ay v.m. les pieças que mas le agradáren.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Then chooſe you out thoſe peeces which best ſhall like you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Eſte ſalpimentéro y éſta copa con ſu ſobre copa, y éſte pichél, y éſta calderéta, y éſta porcelána ſean las priméras.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: This ſalt and pepper boxe, and this cup with his couer, and this pot made ewer wiſe, and this kettle of ſiluer, and this broad cup to drinke in are the best.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: A como hémos de dár porMarco de plato is worth xxxij.s. Engliſh beſide the faſhion. el marco de eſtas pieças?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: What are we to paie for the halfe pound of theſe peeces?

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Por el marco de las llanas me ha de dár. v.m. a çien reáles por las ſinçeládas, a quinze ducádos y por las doradas a treynta ducados.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: For the halfe pounde of theſe plaine peeces your worſhip is to giue mee fiftie ſhillings, for the engrauing fifteene ducates, and for the gilt thirtie ducates.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Si el pedír fuera dár, no ſe avía hecho mala haziénda oy, peró de ❀ el dicho a el hécho ay gran trecho.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: If asking were giuing you had not made an ill match to day, but there is a great diſtance betwixt the worde and the deede.

sp.speaker: Pl
sp.p: Al de menos no lo daré yo por lo, que. v.m. me ha o freçído haſta agora.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: At leaſt I will not giue it for that you haue offered me as yet.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Eſtá tan caro, que yo no ſé que le ofrézca ſi no es vnaA daunce ſo called. Alſo an abatement. báxa.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: You are ſo deere that I know not what I may offer for it, if there bee no abatement.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Eſſa yo la dançaré deſpues que. v. m. aya tañído ſu álta.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: That will I daunce after your worſhip hath ſtrooke the treble.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Mi mas alta Señór, es a ſeis ducados la llána, y a çien reales, la ſinçeláda, y la doráda, a veinte ducádos.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: My highest is ſixe ducates the plaine, and fiftie ſhillings the engrauen, and the gilt twentie ducates.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Muy bien deſpachádo yva yo, mas me tiénen ami de cóſta.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: This buſines is wel diſpatched now, they cost me more.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Pues Señór torne a dançár a vér en que pára.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: But ſir, come backe and daunce againe, to ſee vpon what you ſticke.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: En cada género, le quitaré a. v.m. dos ducádos y no mas.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: In euery kinde of them I will abate two ducates and no more.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Muy mal dançó. v.m. no le tóco mas.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: You daunce very ill, I plaie no more.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Pues yo le aſegúro a. v.m. que no lo halle mas varáto en la calle.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: But I aſſure your worſhip that you cannot finde better cheape in the ſtreete.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Calle que ſi hallare, que donde vna ❀ puerta ſe cierra ciento ſe ábren.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Holde your peace, for I will finde: for where one dore ſhuts a hundred do open.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Si ha de valér mi voto, dezír le he.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: If my voice may preuaile, ile ſtrike the ſtroke.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Diga le v.m. que le ſoy muy devóto.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Let your worſhip ſpeake on, for I am much deuoted.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Pues otro tanto como baxó el platéro, ſuba el ſeñor Tómas y no ſe hable mas.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Then ſo much as the goldſmith hath abated, ſo much let maſter Thomas riſe, and let there be no more wordes.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Porque ſu palabra de v.m. no buelva atrás, &c.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: For that your worſhips worde may bee taken, &c.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: No quería v.m. mas, ora peſelo, peſár malo le dé dios a el diablo.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: You can deſire no more, now waigh it, God giue ill waight to the diuell.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Lleven lo a cáſa que allá lo peſarémos.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Carrie it to your houſe, there we will waigh it.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Móço carga con todo y Lleva lo a caſa.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Sirra, take vp all this and carrie it home.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Han de bolvér ſe luego vueſtras merçédes?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Are your worſhips to come backe againe this way by and by?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: No haſta de aquí a dos oras, que y'mos a comprár otras coſas.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Not till within this two howers, for we goe to buy other things.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.p: Si v. m. es ſervído de que le acompañe, hazér lo he.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: If it pleaſe you, that I go with you, I will.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Guarde Dios a v.m. que no querémos mas compañía.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: God keepe you, we will no more companie.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: En ninguna coſa gaſto el dinero, de mejor gána que en pláta.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: In nothing I ſpend money with a better will then in plate.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Lo que ſe gaſta en plata no es gaſtár, ſi no trocár pieças chicas por pieças grandes.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: That which is laide out in plate is not waſted, but to change ſmall peeces for great peeces.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Y tanbien por que cabe en ella lo que dízen que no cabe en un ſaco que es honra y provecho.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: And alſo there is contayned in it that they ſay is not contained in a ſacke, which isHonor and profit is not held together in one bagge. i. the fine diſhes of earth painted ſuch as are brought from Venice. honor and profit.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Si, por que ſi hombre ſe quiere ſervír con vídrio o china, o bárro, mas cueſta lo que ſe quiebra entre año que la hechura de la plata.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Yea, for if a man will ſerue his turne with glaſſe, or ❀ China mettall, or earth, that which is broken thereof, coſts more in a yeere then the faſhion of the plate.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Y con vna baxilla que hombre cómpra vna vez, tiene para hijos, niétos, y viſniétos.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: And for a cupboord that a man buieth once, he is furniſhed for his children, nephewes, and nephewes children.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Aora vámos a la joyería.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Now let vs goe to the place where they ſell iewels.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Eſſe es vn camíno que yo hago de muy mala gana.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: This is a way that I goe vnwillingly.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Por que razón?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: What is the reaſon?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Por que éſtas joyas ſon como las donzéllas, que miéntras eſtán ençerrádasſon de mucho valór, y en ſacando las fuéra, le pierden todo y no válen nada.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Becauſe theſe iewels are as maidens, that while they are maides and kept in, they are of much value, and in taking them abroad they looſe all, and are worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Si peró, lo que ſe vſa no ſe eſcúſa.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Yea, but that which is a custome cannot be ſhunned, custome needes no excuſe.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Al mal vſo quebrár le la pierna.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: But it is good to breake the legs of an ill custome.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: No queráis ſeñor ponér vos puertas a el campo ni coregír el mundo, que anſi le halláſtes y anſi le havéis de dexár.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I would not haue you Siri. to do things impoſſible. make doores for the fields, and correct the whole world: for ſo you found it, and ſo ſhall you leaue it.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Ora pues corra ol rio por do ſuele, pues ſe arendo la renta con éſtas condiçiones.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Why then let the riuer run where it was wont, ſeeing the thing was hired with theſe conditions.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Entrémos en eſta tiénda que es la mas ríca.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Let vs goe into this ſhop, for it is the richest.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Que manda v.m. ſeñór caualléro, que ha meneſtér?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: What doth your worſhip command, what haue you neede of?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Yo ninguna coſa, éſta ſeñóra, muchas.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I of nothing, this gentlewoman of many things.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Pues pida ſu merçéd, que tódo ſe le dará aquí a muy buen précio.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Then let her require what, and all ſhall be giuen her very good cheape.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Mueſtre me acá algunos tocádos, guirnaldíllas, rapóſos, randas, deſhilados, tocas de todas ſuertes, y tan bien venga la olanda delgada, cambray, y otras ſuertes de liéncos.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Shew me ſome womens head attire, garland head attire, wires of ſiluer, bone worke or bone lace, ſtitched worke, head attire of all ſorts, and alſo bring fine holland, cambrecke, and other ſorts of linnen.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Entre v.m. que todo lo verá aquí.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your worſhip come in, for you ſhall ſee all heere.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Todo eſto es obra toſca mas Prima. i. chief, principall or a ſhee coſen german. prima la quiéro.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: All this is groſſe worke, I woulde ſee more principall.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Para prima Señora no es buena la hija de vueſtro tío?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Will not your vncles daughter ſerue you for a coſen?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Es muy gorda aquella, y por eſſo queria otra mas delgáda.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: This is very courſe, and therfore would I haue other finer.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Pues en eſta caxa verá. v.m. el primór del mundo, todo es obra de Milán.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Then in this cheſt ſhal your worſhip ſee the principallest that is, all is worke of Milan.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Obra de Milán veeme y no me tangas.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Worke of MilanBicauſe they are toies, if you touch them they breake in peeces. ſee me but touch me not.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Nada de eſto me conténta.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: None of theſe pleaſeth me.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Eſpanto me como ſe caſó v.m. ſiendo tan mal contentadíza.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: I woonder how your worſhip married being ſo diuers to pleaſe your fancy.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Fue por que vído a el nóbio de noche, y como dizen entonçes todos los gatos ſon párdos.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: It was bicauſe ſhe ſaw the bridegroome by night, and as they ſaie, then all cats are grey eied.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Mueſtre me otra mejór obra ſi tiene, y dexeſe de preguntár quantos años tengo.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Shewe me ſome better worke, if you haue any, and leaue of to aske how old I am.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Aora éſta es la última pruéva, ve aquí v.m. óbra de argentería ve allí de aljófar, eſtótra de abalório, y éſta de pérlas, eſcoja como peras en tabáque.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Now is the laſt triall, ſee heere worke of ſiluer, there of ſmall pearle, this other of blacke bugles, and this of pearle, chooſe out as peares in a basket.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Por cierto en ruin háto, poco ay que eſcojér.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Verily in a bad flocke, this is but a ſmal choiſe.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: A eſto llama v. m. ruín, reo que es de peór condición que el philóſopho Demócrito, que no hallo coſa en el mundo que no tubiéſſe fálta.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Call you this bad, I beleeue that you are of a woorſe condition then the Philoſopher Democritus, which found nothing in the world, which had not a fault.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Eſſo ſin Democrito lo dígo yo, que no ay coſa perfecta en el mundo.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I ſay this without Democritus, that there is nothing perfect in the world.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Eſſo verificárſe ha, en coſas naturales, que en las de el arte puede aver perfecçión cada vna en ſu género.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: This is to be verified in natural things, for in thoſe things of arte, there may be perfection, euery thing in his kinde.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Pues que penſais vos que es el arte, ſino ymitadór de la natura, y ſi en la natura no ay perfeçión menos la avrá en el arte ſu imitadór.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Why what thinke you that arte is anie thing elſe but a follower of nature, and if nature hath not her perfection, much leſſe ſhall there be anie in arte hir follower.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Yo ſeñor no ſoy philóſopho, ni quiero contender con v. m. mis mercaderías querría que tubiéſſen ſu perfeçión en el préçio.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Sir I am not a Philoſopher, neither will I contende with your worſhip, I would my merchandizes had their perfection in the price.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Si no le tiénen en ſu valór, no le puéden tenér en el préçio.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: If they haue it not in their woorth, they cannot haue it in their price:

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Aora ſeñora véa v.m. lo que mas le conténta, y tome lo que no tengo otra coſa mejór.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Nowe ladie, ſee that which best likes you, and take it, for I haue no better.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Eſte tocádo, eſte cuéllo, éſta gargantílla de perlas, eſte regalillo, y eſte avanillo, eſta dos pares deguentes de flores, y eſta pretína, me paréçen bien, todo lo de más no.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: This kerchiefe, this bande, this neckelace of pearle, this muffe, andBut not of feathers, for they vſe no feather fans in Spaine. this fanne, theſe two paire of gloues perfumed, and this girdle likes me, all the reſt I care not for.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Quanto monta todo eſſo?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: How much comes all this to?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Todo monta tres çientos reáles.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: All comes toi. Seauen pound ten ſhillings. three hundred rials, or ſixe pences.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Tres çientos áños eſté de vn lado quien tal diére.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Let him lie three hundred yeeres on one ſide that ſhould giue ſo much.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Pues por que no le alcançe a v.m. eſſa maldiçión dos çientos, y ochénta.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Then bicauſe this curſe may not light vpon you, giue two hundred and fower ſcore.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: No entiendo bien eſſa cuenta.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I vnderſtand not well this reckoning.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Dos vezes, ſe refiére a ciento y tambien al quarenta.Dos vézes ciento y quarenta.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Twiſe a hundred, and twiſe fortie.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Buena eſtá la copla, no han de ſér mas que dos çiéntos y cinquenta en todo.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: This copla is well, it ſhould be no more then two hundred and fiftie in all.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Con v. m. el perdér es ganár, pues manda que ſe a anſi, yo no hablaré mas palábra.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: With your worſhip to loſe is gaine, ſeeing you commaund ſo, I will not ſpeake a word more.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Para que quiere hablár mas, ſi con las habládas ha hecho ſu agóſto.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Why would you ſpeake any more, if with that which is ſpoken you haue made your haruest.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p:
Por çierto ſeñor de eſte agóſto, poca
coſe cha he cogído.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p:
Truely ſir, of this haruest I haue gotten
but a little fruit.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Señor ſi hiziéra buena ſementéra cogíera mas.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: If you had made your ſeede time better, you had reaped more.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Aun tengo aquí otras muchas mercaderías muy curioſas que v.m. no ha viſto.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Yet haue I many other merchandizes very fine, that your worſhip hath not ſeene yet.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Que ſon?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Sartíllas, joyéles, cintas de reſplandór, brocadétes, rodétes cofias de oro, arandélas, alcacuéllos, gorgueras de réd, camíſas labradas, gargantillas de pérlas, y ámbar, todo género de aféite y de perfúmes, véa v. m. ſi le contenta algo.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Chaines of ieat amber, or ſuch like, tablet iewels, girdles faire to ſee to, cloth of gold the woorſer ſort, head rolles, coifes of gold, ſupporters, gorgets of net worke, wrought ſhirts or ſmockes, necke laces of pearles and amber, all kinde of painting, and perfumes, ſee if you like any.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Otro dia vernémos mas de eſpácio para ver todo eſſo.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: We will come another day, more at leaſure to ſee all this.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Pareçeme ſeñór que es vueſtro ofício, como el de los torneros engaña mucháchos y ſaca dineros.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: It ſeemes to me ſir, that your trade is as that of thei. Make tops for children. turners, which deceiues boies and gets money.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Pues es mi ſeñóra Margaríta muchácho?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Why is my Lady Margaret a boy?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Baſta que ſea engañáda.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: It ſufficeth that ſhe be deceiued.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: A fee que no ha de ſavér poco quien la ha de engñár.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: In faith, he is not to know a little that must deceiue her.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Engañárſe ha ella meſma a ſi miſma.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: She her ſelfe will deceiue her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Como?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Dando dinéros por eſtas bugerías que relúzen yno es óro todo, y quando váya a caſa, ſe hallará con no nada entre dos plátos.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: In giuing money for theſe childiſh toies, which ſhine and yet are not all gold, and when ſhe goes home, it will be founde nothing betweene two platters.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Para que es el dinero ſi no para luzírſe con ello.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Why is money made, but to make ſhew therewith?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Se que eſto aunque relúze no lúze.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I knowe that this, although it glitter double, it ſhines not.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Ya os he dicho ſeñór, que os vais al coriénte de la de mas génte, y pues os caſáſtes como los ótros páſſa por donde los ótros, no andeis por los eſtrémos que todo hombre eſtremádo no eſtá vn dedo de loco, éſtas ſon cargas de el caſamiénto.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I haue alreadie told you ſir, that you goe the common courſe of the moſt, & ſeeing you haue married as other men haue, paſſe that way as other men doe, go not by extremities, for euerie man that is in his extremities, is not a fingers breadth from a foole, theſe be the charges of mariage.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: La ayuda de el eſcaravájo que dexa la carga quanto le ayúdan.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: The helpe of mariageThe nature of the beetle in the cow-turd when another comes to help him, leaues all: ſo in mariage, when another comes to helpe to maintaine his wife, he forſakes her. like the helpe of the beetle vnder the cow-turd, which forſakes the burden as ſoone as they helpe him.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Aora ſeñór éſſas ſon pendénçias que ſe han de reñir en caſa vámonos.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Sir, theſe are quarrels to be chidden out at home. Let vs goe.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Vámos ſeñóra, toma vuéſtro dinero Señór mercadér.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Let vs goe, take your money Master Merchant.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Yo quedo muy conténto y beſo a v.m. las manos y veá ſi me manda ótra coſa.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: I am very well content, and kiſſe your hands, and ſee if you commaund any thing els.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Que con ſalúd que tengamos, nunca mas nos veámos.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Sowe may haue health that we neuer ſee one an other more.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Por çierto Señór, yo no ſoy tan yngráto, que cada dia quería vér a v.m. por mi cáſa.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Truely ſir I am not ſo ingratefull, but that euerie day I would ſee your worſhip by my houſe.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Yo créo que queríades vér mi bólſa mas no a mi.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I beleeue you would ſee my purſe rather then me.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: No ſoy tan codiçióſo como a v. m. le parézco.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: I am not ſo couetous as I ſeeme vnto you.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: No digo yo que lo ſoys, pero apoſtaré que quercis mas un real de a quatro, que uno de a dos.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I ſay not that you are, but I will lay a wager, that you had rather haue two ſhillings than one.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Por adivino le podrían a v. m. caſtigár.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: They might well puniſh you for a ſoothſayer.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Lo que con los ojos véo con el dédo lo adivíno.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: That which with the eies I ſee, I coniecture with my finger.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: A Dios mercadér.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: God be with you merchant.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Beſo a v.m. las manos mi Señóra.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Ladie I kiſſe your hands.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Vámos a ora a la lonja a comprár ſédas.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Let vs goe now to the exchaunge to buy ſilkes.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Que queréis comprár Señora?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: What would you buy?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Que terciopélo, raſo, damáſco, tafetán, riço, gorgarán, chamelóte, laníllas para veſtíros a vos y ami.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: What, plaine veluet, damaske, tafata, vncut veluet, gogram, chamlet, ſarge, to cloath you and my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Para eſſo es meneſtér otro dia y a es tarde vamos a comér que mañána yrémos a comprár eſſo.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: For all this another day will ſerue, it is late now let vs goe to dinner, for to morrow we will goe to buy this.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Vamos pues aunque yo mas quiſiéra que quedára oy todo hecho, que no tenér que ſalír mañana otra buelta.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Let vs goe then, although I would rather that al were done to day, then to come foorth another turne to morrow.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Anda, que bien os holgáis depaſſeár un rato, para que me queréis hazér entendér de el çiélo cebólla?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Goe, for you take good pleaſure to walke a while, wherfore you would make me beleeue the moone is made of a greene cheeſe?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: No ſeáis maliçióſo que no medraréis.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Be not malitious, for you ſhall thriue neuer the ſooner.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Muchácho corre, llama a el platéro que venga a peſár la plata y por ſu dinéro.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Boy, run cal the goldſmith, that he come to waigh the plate and fetch his money:

row.cell: Diálogo tercéro, de un combíte, entre çinco cavalléros amígos, llamádos, Guzman, Rodrígo, don Lorénço, Mendoça, y Oſório, un maestre ſala, y un paje, en el qual, ſe trata, de coſas perteneçièntes a un combíte con otras pláticas, y dichos agúdos.

The thirde Dialogue of a banquet betweene fiue gentlemen friendes, called Guſman, Rodricke, ſir Lorenço, Mendoça, Oſorio, a gentleman vſher, and a Page, in which are handled things belonging to a banquet with other ſpeeches and wittie ſayings.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: OLa, eſtá ay algun paje?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: HOe, is there any Page there?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Señor.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Sáues a cáſa de don Rodrigo?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Dost thou knowe master Rodrick his houſe?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Si Señór.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea ſir.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Pues vée allá, dile que le béſo las mános, y que ſi le paréce óra de que nos veámos.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Then go thither and tell him that I commend me to him, and if he thinke good now, that we may meete togither.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Aquí eſtá un criádo de el Señor don Lorénço.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Heere is a ſeruant of ſir Lorenço.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Entre.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Let him come in.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Don Lorénço mi Señór, béſa a v.m. las mános y embía a ſabér ſi eſtá en caſa, por que tiene un negócio que tratar con. v. m.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Sir Lorenço my master commends him vnto your worſhip, and ſendes me to know whether you be at home, for hee hath a buſines to entreate of with you.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Que beſo a ſu merçed las manos, y que yo fuera a la Suya, a beſárſe las ſi no tuviéra una ocupación forçóſa que eſperár, la qual tanbien toca a ſu merçéd que ſi viniére, ſerá el bien venído y ſe tratará de todo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I thanke him, and I woulde haue come vnto his houſe to haue ſaluted him, if I had not tarried heere about a buſines of importance, the which alſo concernes him, if hee come he ſhall be welcome, and wee will talke at large.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Beſo a v.m. las manos.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: I take my leaue of your worſhip.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Anda con Dios, ola Dezíd a el maeſtre ſala que hága ponér éſſas méſas, que vernán ya los convidádos.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: God be with you. Ho tel the gentleman-uſher that he make the tables to be couered, for the gueſts wil come by and by.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Señór v.m. como ſe quiére ſervír oy, ala Ytaliana, o ala Françéza, o a la Yngleſa, o a la Flaménca, o a la Todéſca?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Sir will your worſhip haue your ſeruice today, after the Italian, after the French, after the Engliſh, after the Flemiſh, or after the Dutch manner?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
De todos eſſos eſtrémos me ſacád vn médio, no quiero tantas çerimònias, como el Ytaliáno, ni quiero tanta curioſidád, como el Françés, ni quiero tanta abundáncia, como el Yngles, ni quiero que la comída ſea tan larga, como el Flaménco ni tan
úmida como el tudéſco, mas de todos eſtos eſtremos, componéme vn médio a la Eſpañola.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
Of all theſe extremes take me out one meane, I will not haue ſo many ceremonies as the Italian, neither will I ſo much curioſitie as the French, neither ſuch abundandance as the Engliſh, neither will I that the meale be ſo long as the Flemmings, nor ſo moist as the
Dutch, but of all theſe extremes, compound me a meane after the Spaniſh faſhion.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Anſi ſe hará como v.m. lo mánda.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: So ſhall it be as your worſhip commandeth.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Vueſtro mayór cuidádo ſéa que la comidá ſea caliénte y la bevída fría.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Let your chiefeſt care be that the meat be hot, andIn Spaine they coole their wine by ſetting the flagons in ſnow water. the drinke coole.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Que vinos quiere v.m.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: What wines will your worſhip haue?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: De todos géneros, bláncos, tinto, halóque, claréte, cándia, ribadáuia, ſan Martín, tóro, y ſidra, porque aya de todo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Of all ſortes, white ſacke, deepe red brackiſh wine, hallocke, claret, candie,Ribadáuia a whitiſh ſacke growing in Galicia about a village called Ribadáuia. Ribadavia,Wine of S. Martin the most delicate wine of Spaine growing about S. Martina towne in the kingdome of Toledo in Spaine. S. Martin, Toro, and Cider, for that there may be of euery ſorte.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Aquí viéne el ſeñór don Rodrígo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Heere commeth maſter Roderick.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: O ſeñór. v.m. y las buenos áños.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Oh ſir you are as welcome as the good yeere.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Beſo a.v.m. las manos.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Sir I thanke you hartely.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Como eſtá. v.m. paréçe que coxéa.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: How do you ſir, it ſeemes you halt.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Díme vn golpe a el apeár de el cavállo en eſta eſpinilla.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I hit my ſelfe a blowe in lighting from my horſe, in this ſhin bone.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: En ora mala ſéa, veámos ſi es algo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: In ill time, let vs ſee if it be any thing.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: ❀ No ſeñór, ſi no que es como dízen dolór de cobdo, dolor de eſpóſo, duele mucho y dúra poco.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: No ſir, it is (as they ſay) like the paine of a blow on the elbow, or the ſorrowe of a bridegrome,Bicauſe they haue had ſmall conuerſation togither to increaſe loue. it greeueth much and is quickly done.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Mas vale anſi.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: It is the better.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Como tiene. v.m. a mi ſeñóra doña Maria y a toda ſu caſa?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: How doth my lady Mary your wife, and all your familie.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: A ſervíçio de. v.m. aunque ella por no avér me ynbídia díxo, que pues yo comía con mis amígos, ella ſe quería yr a comér con ſus amígas.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: At your ſeruice, although ſhe ſaies (not bicauſe ſhe enuies me) that ſince I banquet with my friendes, ſhe would go to dinner to hir friends.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Hízo ſu merçéd muy diſcretaménte, en pagár le a. v.m. en la miſ- ❀ ma monéda.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: She dealt very diſcreetely to paie you with the ſame money.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Todos eſtos ſeñóres conbidádos eſtán aqui, y la comída a púnto quando vueſſas merçedes fuéren ſervídos, ſe podran aſentár.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: All the gentlemen that are inuited are heere, and dinner is readie, when your worſhips pleaſe, you may ſit downe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: ❀ Señór don Lorénço. v.m. tiéne las mañas de el Rey que adonde no eſtá no le hállan.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Sir Lorenço you haue the propertie of a king, that where he is not, there they finde him not.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Y v. m. quiere pareçérſe Alçina de quien dize Orlando que por engáño, tray'alos hombres a gozár de ſus regálos.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: And you will be like Alcina of whom Orlando maketh mention, which brought men to take pleaſure in her dainties to entrap them.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Pero, no ſerán vueſſas merçédes convertídos en animáles como ella hazía.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: But you ſhall not be turned into beaſtes as ſhe turned them.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
❀ No me aſegúro, que dexe de bolverſe
vérſe alguno en çórra.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
I am not aſſured of that, for ſome of vs
may ſuffer himſelfe to bei. To be drunk turned into a foxe.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: ❀ De buen vino quien quiera ſe caça vna en el áño.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Whoſoeuer loues good wine,i. Whips the cat, or is drunke once a yeere. hunts the foxe once a yeere.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Cada vno ſu alma en ſu palma, qual el tiempo tal ſea el tiénto. Ea Señores tómen ſillas v. s. mercedes y ſienten ſe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Euery one holdes free will in his hands, as the time requires ſo frame thy deſires. Go to gentlemen betake your ſelues to your chaires and ſit downe.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Déxenos v. m. ante todas coſas contenplár vn rato la curioſidád de la méſa.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Suffer vs I praie aboue all things to beholde a while the curiouſnes of this table.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: ❀ No tiene mas pieças vn juego de maſtre corál, que eſtán hechas de las ſervillétas.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: A iuglar hath no more inuentions and peeces then are made in theſeTable napkins at a banquet or inuiting in Spaine ſet out with diuers faſhions, as of beaſtes, birds, &c. this the Maestreſala alwaies doth. table napkins.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Yo aqui véo vna galéra, que no le fálta mas, que la chúſma y palaménta.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I ſee heere a gally, there wants nothing but the gallie ſlaues and the oares.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Pues acá eſtá vn cavalloque no ſé yo, ſi el cavallo de Tróya éra tan bien hécho.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: And here is a horſe, that I know not if the horſe of Troy were ſo wel made.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: A mi me ha caído enſuerte el eſcudo de Hércules.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: And heere hath fallen to my lot Hercules ſhielde.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Y eſte que eſtá aqui, que es?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: And this which is heere what is it?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: A mi me paréçe, ques vna pirámida de las de Egípto.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It ſeemes to me to be one of theThere were many Piramides, but two of them were reckoned one of the ſeuen wonders of the world. Piramides of Egypt.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: O es el ſepulcro de máuſalo, o la torre de babel.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Or it is MauſalusWhich for the magnificence thereof was accompted one of the woonders of the world, and was built by his wife Queene Artemiſia. Tombe, or the tower of Babell.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Aóra déxen eſſo vueſſas marçédes y ſiéntenſe, ſi, ſon ſervídos.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Now leaue off this, and ſit downe if it pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: No ſe ipuede dexár de mirár el caſtillo de la enſaláda.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: One cannot chooſe but looke vpon the ſallet made like a castle.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Por mi vida, que no tiéne mejór viſta el de Milán.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: In faith the caſtle of Milan is no better to ſee to.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Si cada coſa ſe ha de mirár de por ſi, yr ſe nos ha el dia en flóres. Cada vna tire ſu ſilla, que éſta no es méſa de cumplimiéntos.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: If we must ſtand to behold euery thing by it ſelfe, the time will be gone without doing any thing. Euerie one draw his chaire, for this is not a table of complements.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: No los déve avér entre amigos.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: They ought not to be among friends.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yo ſoy ynimiçíſſimo de çerimónias.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I am the greatest enemie in the worlde to ceremonies.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: ❀ A mi no me paréçen bien ningunas, ſi no ſon las que haze la ygléſia.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: None of them ſeeme good vnto me, except it be thoſe which the church makes.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Ola, plátos, tome v. m. eſſe ſeñór don Lorénço.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Hola,They eate in little diſhes their meate & not vpon trenchers in Spaine. diſhes. Take this ſir Lorenſo.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Haga v.m. paraſi, que lo miſmo hará cada vno.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Make a diſh for your ſelfe, for euerie one will do the like.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: No ſe qual ſea mejór v'ſo eſte que vſamos en Eſpáña o el que ſe v'ſa en ynglatérra.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I knowe not which is the better custome which we vſe in Spaine, or that which is vſed in England.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Que es el v'ſo de ynglatérra?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What is the maner of England?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Comér priméro lo cozído, que lo aſſádo, nos ótros hazémos a el revés.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: To eate their ſodde meate firſt before their roast, we doe quite contrarie.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Segun réglas de mediçína primero ſe déven comér los manjáres que ſon mas duros de digeſtión

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: According to the rules of Phiſicke, men ought firſt to eate thoſe meates which are moſt hard of digeſtion.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Y eſtá eſſo en razón para que ſe venga a hazér la digeſtión en vn tiempo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: And that ſtands with reaſon, bicauſe digeſtion may be made togither.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Pues que ſéa mas duro de digeſtión, lo aſádo que lo cozído, es coſa clára.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Then that roaſtmeate is more hard of digeſtion then the ſodde, it is a thing out of doubt.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Yo como ſoy mas golóſo, hallo ótra razón.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I that am a great eater, finde another reaſon.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Qual es?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Que toda coſa aſſada, es mas ſabróſa que la cozída, y áſſi, yo lo querría a el princípio por que ſobre buen cimiénto buen edificio ſe háze.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: That euery thing roaſted is more ſweet to the taſte then the ſodde, and ſo therefore woulde I haue it at the firſt, for vpon a good foundation, a good building is made.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: Pues yo aunque cállo, piédras apaño.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: He that is ſilent gathereth reaſons to confute his aduerſarie.Although I hold my peace, I gather vp ſtones.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Anda v. m. diſcréto, que obéja que bála bocado piérde.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: You ſaie very right, for that ſheepe that bleateth looſeth a bit.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: A mi me paréçe que ándan ya en ſeco éſtos molinos.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Me thinkes theſe milles go now drie.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: De la boca me lo quitó v.m.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: You tooke it out of my mouth.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Pues ſi yo lo quité, júſto es que yo lo pónga. Ola, dad nos de bevér, cada vno pida lo que mas guſto le diére, que de todo ay.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: If I tooke it out, it is reaſon I ſhoulde put it in. Hola giue vs drinke, euerie one aske for that which he likes beſt, for there is of euery ſorte.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Páje yo ſoy muy devóto de a quel ſanto que partió la capa con el pobre.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Page, I haue great deuotion to thatSaint Martin gaue a peece of his cloake to a poore man, and wine of Saint Martin the moſt daintie of all Spaine. Saint which departed with a peece of his cloake to a poore man.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A buen entendedór pocas palabras, de lo de ſant Martin quiére v.m.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To a good vnderstander a worde is enough, you woulde haue that of Saint Martin.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: O como éres diſcréto, Dios me de ſiempre contienda, conquien me entiénda.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: O how you are in the right, God ſend me to diſpute alway with him that vnderstandeth what I ſay.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Pues yo vn tiempo fui toréro, y me holgáva ſiempre conHe alludes to wine of Toro, wines called vino de Toro, which is a Bull, as alſo a townes name. toros bravos.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I was once a courſer of buls, and I alwaies tooke pleaſure in fierceHe alludes to wine of Toro, wines called vino de Toro, which is a Bull, as alſo a townes name. buls.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Señores yo brindo a quien toſſiére.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I drinke to him that ſhall cough.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: ❀ Vala me Dios y que resfriádos que eſtámos todos, no ſe tóſſe mas en vn ſermón de quaréſma.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: God bleſſe me, and what coldes we haue all taken, there is not more coughing in a lenten ſermon.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
Eſſa gráçia, dízen que tenémos los Eſpañóles que ſómos como
mónas amígos de hazér lo que vémos hazér a otros.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
This faſhion (they ſay) that we Spanyards haue, that we are as apes,
which doe that which they ſee others to doe.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: ❀ Anſi dize vn refrán, ſi no hago lo que véo, todo me méo.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: So ſaith the prouerbe, If I doe not what I ſee, I all to bepiſſe me.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Cada vno aſga de ſu perdíz, y la aderéçe como mejór le pareçiére, ay aſtán limónes, limas, naránjas, pimiénta, y todo lo demás.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Euery one fasten on his partridge and order him as best ſhall ſeeme good vnto him, there are limons and orenges, pepper, and all things elſe.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: ❀ La perdiz, dízen los médicos, que ſe a de comér entre tres compañéros paraque no haga mál.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: A partridge, as phiſitions ſay, is to be eaten betweene three companions, that he may doe no harme.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Tiénen razón que han de ſer el hombre, vn gato, y vn pérro.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: They ſay true, that is, betweene a man, a cat and a dog.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Vuéſtras mercédes no han notado la variedád de aſſádos que aqui nos han traído.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: You haue not marked the varietie of the roast, which here they haue brought vs.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Que eſtá debaxo de aquella enramáda?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: What is vnder thoſe greene boughes?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Vna cabéça de javalí.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: The head of a wilde boare.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Eſtónçes rámos de tavérna ſon aquellos.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Then it is the buſh of a tauerne.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Antes a el contrário que el ramo en la tabérna llama a los borrachos a el vino, y aquellos lláman a el miſmo vino, aſi como la piédra ymán el azéro.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Rather the contrarie, for the tauerne buſh inuites thoſe that loue drinke to the wine, and theſe boughes inuites or drawes vnto it wine it ſelfe, euen as the loadſtone draweth to it ſteele.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: A Señór Mendóza partí de eſſe Xigóte con vueſtros amígos.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: A maſter Mendoza, part this roast leg of mutton with your friends.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: ❀ Señór el mio murió ſúpito.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Sir mine died ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Paréçe que havéis reſpondído, un gran A deféſio .i. diſparate.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: It ſeemes you haue anſwered with a ſpeech quite beſide the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Pues aunque lo paréçe, no lo es, que a ſú provecho ha habládo el ſeñór Mendóza.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Although it ſeeme, it is not ſo, for maſter Mendoza hath ſpoken it for his aduantage.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Pues, ſi no nos lo declara, no ſaldrémos de dúbda.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: But if he do not expound it, we ſhall not know what it meanes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Señór, es el caſo, que dos compañéros llegáron a una vénta y como no uviéſſe otra coſa que çenár, que una gallína aſsáda, el uno de ellos que tenía buena hambre, y éra hombre aſtúto, díxo a el otro compañero, entanto que yo apáro éſta gallina, contáme de que murió vueſtro padre: el otro ſe començó a enternecér, y con lágrimas le relató un proçéſo bien largo de la enfermedád de ſu padre, y como avía muerto, en lo qual
tardó tanto, que quando acordó ya el otro ſe avía comído, caſi toda la gallina, el hallando ſe burládo, quíſo eſquitárſe y díxo le compañéro, pues yo os he contádo la muerte de mi padre, contáme vos, la, de el vueſtro, el compañero, por no perdér La parte que le quedáva y concluír preſto razónes, reſpondió, Señor, el mio murió ſúpito: con la qual Repuéſta el otro quedó muy burládo y el le ayudó a deſpachár lo que faltáva.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Sir, this it is, that two companions came to an Inne, vpon the high way, and as there was nothing elſe to ſuppe withall, but one hen roaſted: one of them which was well hungrie & a craftie fellow, ſaide to the other companion, in the meane while that I breake vp and order this hen, recount vnto me whereof your father died. The other began to be tender harted, and with teares related vnto him a long proceſſe of the ſicknes of his father, & how he died, wherin he ſtood ſo long, that when he remembred
himſelfe, the other had alreadie eaten almost all the hen, he finding himſelfe mocked, would quite himſelfe, and ſaide vnto him, companion, ſeeing I haue tolde you the death of my father, doe you tell me now the death of your father: his companion for that hee would not looſe that part which remained, and becauſe he would be ſhort anſwered, Sir, my father died ſuddenly, with which anſwere he gaue his fellow a ſcoffe, and himſelfe time to diſpatch the reſt.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Pues aquí no corre eſe riéſgo.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: But here is not the like danger.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No, pero yo ſoy como el cuclíllo que no canto bien haſta que tengo el eſtómago lléno.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Although not, I am like the cuckow, which ſing not vntill I haue my ſtomacke full.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Con liçençia de el ſeñór Guzman quiéro ymbiár eſta pella de manjár blanco a un amigo.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: With leaue of Maſter Guzman, I will ſend this round ball ofA meat made of breaſts of hens, milke, ſugar, rice beaten, and ſpices mixed withall, one of the daintieſt meates vſed. Manjár blanco to a friend.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Con mi liçénçia no yrá ſola ſi no la acompáña v. m. con aquel pávo, o eſte faiſan o el francolín.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: With my leaue it ſhall not goe alone, but that you accompanie with it, this peacock, this feaſant, or this francolin bird.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Por vida de don Lorénço es amigo o amiga?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I pray you hartily Sir Lorenço, is it a he friend or ſhe friend?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: ❀ Quereis que confieſſe ſin tormento.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Will you that I confeſſe without the racke?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: ❀ Y quando os le den antes mártir que confeſſor.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: And when they doe racke you, rather prooue a martyr then a confeſſor.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: ❀ O que reverenda que viéne nueſtra madre la olla.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: O what a reuerend perſon comes here, our mother the meate.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Y bien adornáda de todas ſus pertenénçias.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: And well adorned with all her appurtenances.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yo deſéo ſavér, donde o porque le llamaron olla podrída?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I deſire to knowe, from whence or why they called itA rotten or putrified pot. Alſo a hotch-potch of many meates togither Olla podrida.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Metaforicaménte, porque aſsí como en vn muladár ſe púdren muchas cóſas diferéntes, y de todas ſe haze la baſúra aſsí la olla que es conpuéſta de muchas coſas ſe viéne a hazér vn guizádo o potáje.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Metaphorically, becauſe euen as in a dung hill many different things rot together, and of all theſe they make dung for the field: euen ſo the pot which is compounded of many things is made one iellie or potage.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Tan buena metáfora fue eſſa como el que llamó Rey a el que guarda los puercos.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: This was as good a metaphor as that of him, which called the king the keeper of hogs.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Por mi paſſatiempo yo me quiero poner acontár de quantas coſas eſtá compuéſta ſu mercéd de nueſtra olla, carnero, váca, toçino.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: For my recreation I will ſet my ſelfe to reckon, of how many things this worſhipfull the pot, is compounded, firſt mutton, beefe, and bacon.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: ❀ Eſſas ſon las tres poténcias de la olla como las de la alma, memória, entendimiénto, voluntád.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Theſe are the three powers of the pot, as the three powers of the ſoule, memorie, vnderſtanding, will.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Luego ſe ſigue repóllo, návos, çevollas, ajos.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Now followe cabbage, turneps, onyons, garlicke.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: ❀ Eſſas ſon las quatro virtúdes cardináles.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Theſe be the fower cardinall vertues.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Cavéças y pies de áves, culantro verde, alcarabéa, comínos, todas eſpécias, las de mas yérvas, y no las conóſco, otro las quénte.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: The heades and feete of birdes, the herbe carobes or S. Iohns herbe, comines, all ſortes of ſpices, the moſt part of herbes, I knowe them not, let another ſpeake of them.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: Lo que yo contaré deſpues, ſerá lo bien que me ha ſabído.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: That which I will ſaie of it ſhall be the good I haue taſted in it.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: De el marques chapin vitélo Ytaliáno, que fue uno de los mas valiéntes ſoldados que ha tenido aquella naçión, ſe quenta que quando fue a Eſpáña le diéron tanto guſto eſtas ollas, que nunca querría comér en ſu caſa, ſi no que y endo por la calle olía en caſa de algun labradór rico, adonde ſe comía alguna olla de éſtas, y ſe entráva allá y ſe a ſentáua a comér con el.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Of marques Chapin Vitelo, an Italian, which was one of the most valiant ſouldiers, which that nation hath had, it is ſaide, that when he went to Spaine, theſe hodgpots liked his taſte ſo well, that he neuer woulde dine in his owne houſe, but that going in the ſtreete, where hee ſmelt in the houſe of any rich farmer, where any of theſe hodgpots were eaten, there he entred, and ſate downe to diner with him.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: Devíalo de hazérpor comér a coſta agéna.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Belike hee did that to dine at another mans charges.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: No, que antes que ſaliéſſe mandáva a ſu mayordómo pagáſſe toda la coſta de la olla.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: No, for before he went out of dores hee commanded his ſteward to pai • all the cost of the hodgepot.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Pare, mira como pónes eſſe plato no deribes el ſaléro.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Staie, looke howe thou putteſt this platter, do not throwe downe the ſalt-ſeller.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Si, ſi, guarda, que es el aguéro de los mendózas.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Yea, yea, take heede, for it is the Mendozas malum omen.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Ya todos ſomos Mendózas en eſſo.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: We are all Mendozas in this.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Eſſa raſtra nos quedó de la gentilidád.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: This trace doth remaine to vs from the Gentiles.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Hemos viſto eſperiéncias muy verdadéras.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wee haue ſeene many true examples heereof.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: ❀ Créo en Dios y no en putas viéjas.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I beleeue in God, and not in olde wiues tales.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Eſſas ſon de las que yo me procúro ſiempre guardár.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Thoſe are they from which I alwaies ſeeke to keepe my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: O ſeñor Guzman para que es eſto que ſe trae agora?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: O maſter Guzman, wherefore is this that they bring now?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Dízen que pará comér.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: They ſaie for to eate.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Si, peró éra meneſtér hazér nuévos eſtómagos, en que e chállo.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Yea, but it were need to make ſtomacks to receiue it.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p:
Mandárlos hazér de barro a truéco
de poco dinéro.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p:
Cauſe them to bee made of claie, for a
ſmall price of money.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Eſtas tortas reáles, ſon como cuerpo que no ocúpa lugár.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Theſe riall tartes are as the bodie which filleth no place.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Yo tengo de provár eſta pepitória.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I will prooue thisMade of the heades, liuers, harts, breaſtes, feete, of duckes geeſe, or other birds, &c. Pepitório or gallimaufrie.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Yo conelOf paſte of almondes and ſugar, egges, breaſts of hens, milke, cynamon, and diuers ſorts of ſpices verie like Manjar blanco. manjár reál me acomódo.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I do applie my ſelfe to this riall diſh of meate.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: No ay quien pruéve eſótros guiſados, éſtos torreſnos lampreádos, aquel adobado, el carnéro verde, las albóndigas, ni lo de mas.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Is there no bodie to prooue theſe other meates, theſe hogs liuers with the hogs caule fried with the fat, that hodgepot of mutton, mutton ſtuffed with parſly, the chopped meat made into round bals, neither the rest.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: ❀ Todo éſſo es como Pedro por de mas.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: All this is as Peter too much.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: O como alla voy no hago mengua.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Oh as I goe there I neuer faile.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Alçalo pues muchacho deſembaráça y trae aquella fruta de ſartén.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Take off boy, rid the table, and bring theſe fritters.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Aqui eſtá ſeñor, y la melója y tódo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Here it is Sir, and theWine ſodden to the third part for a ſauce for the fritters. Melója and all.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Eſſo allá a los aguados, que la borracha no quiere páſſa.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: That there is for thoſe that drinke water, for one that loues wine loues not to eateBut ſalt meats to make them drinke. raiſins.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Traé pues la fruta de póſtre, camuéças, péras, azeitúnas, nuézes, avellánas, y la cája de mermeláda.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Bring fruit for the last ſeruice, pippins, peares, oliues, wallnuts, ſmall nuts, and the boxe of marmalade.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Haſta quando hemos de comér?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Till when ſhall we eate?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: ❀ Haſta enfermár, como dize el refrán.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Vntill we be ſicke, as ſaith the prouerbe.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Y deſpues ayunár haſta ſanár.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: And afterward to fast till wee bee in health.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Levánta eſta méſa paje, que es ya gula tanto comér.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Take away this table, Page, for it is gluttonie to eate ſo much.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: ❀ Yo he perdido la gana, como ſi me la quitáran con la mano.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I haue lost my ſtomack, as though they had taken it from me with ones hand.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: El mejór remédio, que halláron los filóſofos, contra la hambre, fue eſte.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: The best remedie that euer philoſophers found against hunger, was this.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: ❀ Eſa filoſofía algo es gruéſſa de hiláça.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: This philoſophie is ſomewhat of a groſſe threed.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Mejór ſe podrá dezír verdád apuráda que ya ſaveís lo que es.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Better may you ſay a refined truth, you know what I meane.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: ❀ Ya ſe que verdádes apurádas ſon neçedádes.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I knowe that refined truthes are fooleries.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Mas pulído lo quería yo dezír.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I would giue it a better terme.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Como?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Yndiſcreçiónes.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Indiſcretions.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p:
Tanto monta cortár, como deſatár,
como díxo Alexandre.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p:
It comes all to one, to cut it off or vntie
it, as Alexander ſaid.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: Ola paje, tráe unos náipes entretengámos el tiempo.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Hola page, bring cardes, let vs paſſe away the time.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Eſſo me conténta, vengan que deſséo eſquitár me de un eſcudo que perdí eſtótro día.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That pleaſeth me well, let them come, for I deſire to quit my ſelfe of a crowne, that I lost this other day.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: ❀ No me péſa ami de que mi híjo juégue, ſino de que ſe quiere eſquitár.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: It greeues me not that my ſonne is a gameſter, but that he will goe to quit himſelfe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: El tahur, chica ocaſión ha meneſtér para bolvér a el juégo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The gameſter requireth but ſmall occaſion to returne to plaie.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: A mi me pareçe que ſola una.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: It ſeemes to me but one onely.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Qual es?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Tenér dinéros.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: That he haue money to doe it.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Ni al tahúr faltó que jugár, ni al golóſo que comér, ni al enduradór que endurár, ni al borácho que bevér.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Neither hath the gameſter euer wanted money to play, nor the gluttonous to eate, nor the patient to ſuffer, nor the louer of drinke to drinke.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: Aqui eſtán los náipes, que jugarémos?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Here are the cards, what ſhall we play at?

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Iuguémos gana piérde.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Let vs play at loadam.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Es juego de mucha fléma.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is a plaie of much patience.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Pues séa a el triúnfo.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Then let it be at trumpe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Quéde para los viéjos.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Let that be for old men.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: A los çientos.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: At mount ſant.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Deſvanéçe ſe me la cabéça, de eſtár ſiempre contándo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It makes my head to be in a ſwoune, to be alwaies counting.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Menos os agradará el chilindrón.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Leſſe will the play of Chilindron like you.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: E'ſſe para las mugéres de tras de los tiçónes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: That is for women by the fire ſide.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: No es, ſi no que vos no queréis juego de virtúd, ſi no de arrebáta cápas.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: It is not, but that you will not haue any game of vertue but ſweepe ſtake play.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Para que hemos de eſtár gaſtándo ❀ tiempo, ſino lo que ſe a de empeñár, venda ſe, como dízen.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Wherefore ſhould we waste time, but that which we must pawne, let vs ſell our right as they ſay.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: Si, por que haziénda hécha, no da priéſſa.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Yea, but ones ſubstance made vp, let there be no haſte to loſe ones money.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: ❀ Y mas quando le gánan a el hombre ſu dinero, le quitan preſto decuidá do.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: And moreouer, when they win a mans money from him, they ſtraightway take him out of care.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: He aqui eſtán los naipes juguémos treínta por fuérça, o los albúres que todos éſtos ſon buenos juegos.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Behold here are the cardes, let vs play at thirtie perforce or Albures, for theſe are good plaies.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: Yo no ſoy amigo de ellos, ſi no de juegos de primór, como el Reynádo, el tres dos y as, triunfo calládo y ótros ſemejantes.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I loue not theſe but games of chiefest price, as the Reynádo, the three, two and ace, ſtill trumpe, and other the like.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Ora por quitár todos de contiénda yo quiéro dar vn médio y ſea eſte la priméra.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Now to take away all occaſion of ſtrife, I will giue a meane, and let it be Primera.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Muy bien avéis dicho que es médio entre los eſtrémos.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: You haue ſaide very well, for it is a meane betweene extremes.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Yo entiéndo que ſe llamó priméra, porque tiene el priméro lugár entre los juegos de náypes.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I take it that it is called Primera, becauſe it hath the firſt place at the play at cardes.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: Alto, que ha de ſer el tanto?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Let vs goe, what is the ſumme that we play for?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Quatro reáles y dies y ſeis de ſaca.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Two ſhillings ſtake, and eight ſhillings rest.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Pues barajá eſſos naipes bien.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Then ſhuffle the cardes well.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Yo álço por mano, figura úvo de ſér, no querría yo yr hecho figura ſin blanca.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I lift to ſee who ſhall deale, it muſt be a coate card, I would not be a coat with neuer a blanke in my purſe.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: Yo un ás alçé.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I did lift an ace.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Yo un quátro.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I a fower.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yo vn ſe is, con que ſoy mano.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I a ſixe, whereby I am the eldeſt hand.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Véngan las cartas que yo las doy una, dos, tres, quatro. Vna, dos, tres, quatro.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Let the cardes come to me, for I deale them, one, two, three, fower, one, two, three, fower.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Paſo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Paſſe.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: Paſo.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Paſſe.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Paſo.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Paſſe.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Enbído un tanto.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I ſet ſo much.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No le quiero.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I will none.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: No le quiero.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Ile none.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Yo por fuérça avré de querér, echád cartas.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I must of force ſee it, deale the cards.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Echad me quatro cartas he aqui mi tanto.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Giue me fower cards, Ile ſee as much as he ſets.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: He aqui el mio, cada uno meta el ſuyo.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: See heere my reſt, let euery one be in.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Buelvo a paſár.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I am come to paſſe againe.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: Yo tanbien.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: And I too.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Yo hago lo própio.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I do the ſelfe ſame.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Yo enbído mi reſto.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I ſet my rest.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Quiero le.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Ile ſee it.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: Yo tanbien.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I alſo.

sp.speaker: b.L.
sp.p: Pues yo no me puedo echár.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I cannot giue it ouer.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yo híze una primerilla.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I was a ſmall prime.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Yo voy a flux.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I am fluſh.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No querría yo que le hiziéſſedes.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I would you were not.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Es éſſa buena promixidád?

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Is this good neighbourhood?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: ❀ La caridád bien ordenáda comiénça de ſi míſmo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Charitie well placed, doth first beginne with ones ſelfe.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: Yo he hecho cinquénta y çinco con que máto ſu priméra.

sp.speaker: O.
sp.p: I made fiue and fiftie, with which I win his prime.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Yo flux con que tíro.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: I fluſh whereby I draw.

sp.speaker: d.R.
sp.p: No juégo masa éſte juégo.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: I play no more at this play.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Ni yo a ótro ninguno que voy a vn
negócio que me ympórta.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Neither I at any other, for I muſt goe
about a buſines that concernes me.

sp.speaker: d.L.
sp.p: Pajes toma cada quatro reáles de baráto.

sp.speaker: L.
sp.p: Pages take euerie one two ſhillings a peece of the winnings.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Centuplum acipias.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I pray God you may receiue it a hundred fold.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: En el çielo lo halle v.m. colgádo de vn garaváto.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In heauen I pray God you may finde it hanged on a hooke.

row.cell: Diálogo quarto, entre dos amígos llamádos el uno Mora, el otro Aguilàr y un moço de mulas y una Ventéra, trátan ſe en el de las cóſas tocántes a el camíno con muy gracióſos dichos y chíſtes.

The fourth Dialogue betweene two friendes, the one called Mora, the other Aguilar and a mulettier and a woman Inkeeper: Heerein are handled things pertaining to the way with very pleaſant ſayings, and gracious ſpeeches.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: OLa Pedro havéis traído mi mula?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: HO Peter haue you brought my mule?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Señór ſi, aquí eſtá la mohína.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea ſir, heere is the Mohína, ſignifieth anger, paſſion, diſquietnes, churliſhnes. Alſo a ſhee mule with a blacke face or muſſell, alwaies hauing iadiſh trickes. Mohina.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Mohina es nunca buéna.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Mohina is neuer good.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Por que, Señor?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Why ſir?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: ❀ Por que ni mula mohína, ni moça marína, ni moço Pedro en cáſa, ni Abád por Vezíno, ni poyo a la puerta, no es bueno.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Bicauſe neither a mule with a blacke muſſell, nor a maide that hath paſſed the ſea, nor a ſeruanti. A knauiſh ſeruant. Peter in ones houſe, nor a neighbour abbot, nor a Well at the dore, is euer good.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yo le prométo a v. m. que es mejór éſta, que la que araſtró a el cura quando dezía Dominus providebit.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I promiſe your worſhip that ſhe is better then that which dragged alongA curate falling off his mule hanging in the ſtirrup was dragged ſo a long, till a laborer in the fielde tooke him out. the curate when he ſaid, Dominus prouidebit.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Es vieja?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Is ſhe old?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Nunca la vi naçér, mas yo créo que mas viéja éra ſu madre.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I ſawe hir not foaled, but I beleeue that hir dame was elder.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Tira cozes?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Doth ſhe kicke?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Nunca una ſola.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Shee neuer giues one alone.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Siempre ſon a pares, camína bien?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: They are alwaies by couples, doth ſhee trauell well?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Todo lo que ánda ſe dexa atrás.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: She neuer trauels but ſhee leaues the way behinde her.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Tan buenas grácias tiéne a fee que me va enamorándo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: She hath ſo good tricks in faith, that I am in loue with her.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Vna tiene ſobre todas que es grande Oſtróloga.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: One ſhe hath aboue all, for ſhe is a great Aſtronomer.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Como anſi?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Conoçe mejór que vn relóx quando es médio dia, y luego pide çebáda, y ſi no ſe la dan dize
lunes y no ay paſſár de allí.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
She knowes better then a clocke when it is noone, and foorthwith ſhe lookes for prouender, and if they
giue her none, then ſhe ſaies Lunes, meaning heere the grunting voice of a mule or horſe, but Lunes properly ſignifieth Mondaie. lunes, and ſtirres not a foote from the place.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Búen remédio para eſſo rogár ſe lo con la eſpuéla.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: A good remedie for this to intreat her with the ſpurre.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Es flaquíſſima de memória.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: She is most weake of memorie.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Como?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Aunque le hínguen vn palmo de eſpuéla a dos paſſos que da, ſe le ha ya oluidádo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Although you ſtrike into her a hands breadth of the ſpurre, within two ſteps after ſhe hath forgotten it.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: ❀ Traélda, no ſe me da náda, que topado ha Sancho con ſu Roçíno y ſi ella es traydora yo ſoy alebóſo, y nos entenderémos a coplas.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Bring her, I care not, for Sancho hath met with his palfrey, and if ſhe be aA ſcabbed horſe fit for a ſcalde ſquier. knauiſh iade I am as knauiſh a rider, and we ſhall vnderstand one another by couples.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ En yendo v.m. con cuydádo hará de ella çéra y Pávilo que ella con quien ſe deſcuyda úſa ſus tretas.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: You trauelling with hir, with good heed, you may agree like theThe waxe of the candle, and the weeke of the candle, i • al in al waxe and the weeke, but ſhee with one that is not aware of hir will plaie hir part like a fencer.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Echalde la ſilla, apretálde bien la síncha ponélde gurupéra atahárre y pretál, acorta eſſos eſtribos que yo me averné con ella.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Set on the ſaddle, girde hir harde with the girts, put on the crooper and poitrell, make ſhorter theſe ſtirrups, for I will make agreement with hir.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Quiero ponér, vnas aciónes nuévas por mas ſeguridád.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I will put on newe ſtirrup leathers for more ſecuritie.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Echálde el freno, ponéd le bien el bocádo y acortád la cabeçáda mirád ſi eſtá bien herráda de todos quatro pies.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Put on the bridle, make the bit fast, make ſhorter the headſtall, looke if ſhe be well ſhod of all fower feete.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Manos, i. the forefeete. En las mános, buenas herradúras y clávos tiene, de los pies de ſuyo gaſta.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: On the forefeete ſhe hath good ſhooes and nailes, on the hinder feete ſheWith kicking. weares out hir owne hoofe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Echáldo el coxín y porta mantéo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Put the cuſhion on the ſaddle and the portemanteau.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Ea compañero hémos ya de acabár de ſalír oy de aqui?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How now companion, ſhall we make an end that we may get hence to day?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Ya vos venís cavalgando?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What are you come already, and a horſbacke?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: ❀ Vos tardáis mas en componér os que vna nóbia.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You tarrie longer in ſetting your ſelfe in order then a bride.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Vueſtra mula es manſa?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Is your mule gentle?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Como vna borrega no lo veis que ſufre maléta.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As gentle as a lambe, do you not ſee he beares a maile.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: ❀ De el água mánza me libre dios, que de la braba yo me guardaré.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: From the ſtilwater, God keepe me, from the raging, I will keepe my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Ala vueſtra, baſta le ſer mohína.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: For your mule, it is ſufficient, that ſhe is a mule with a blacke muzzle.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Mal conocéys vos aquien nunca viſtes, pues a fee que eſtá granduáda por zalamánca.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: You hardly know him whom you neuer ſaw, but in faith this mule hath taken degree in Zalamanca.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: En que facultád?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In what arte?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: En la de la vellaqueriá, bachilléra en ártes de tirár cózes, licenciáda en léyes de véntasy de meſónes, y doctóra es en aſtrología y matemáticas.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: In the arte of villanie, Bachelor of the kicking art, Licentiat of lawes in Innes, and doctor in Aſtrologie, and the Mathematikes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Por eſſo eſtá ſiempre mirando a el çielo.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: For this cauſe, ſhee lookes alwaies towards heauen.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Es por contemplár los áſtros y planétas y ſignos y ſus cúrſus.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is to contemplate the ſtars, planets, and ſignes, and their courſes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Vámos de aquí que tenémos larga la jornada.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Let vs go, for we haue a long iourney.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Quantas leguas penſáys caminár oy?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How many leagues do you thinke to trauell to day?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yo querría que doze.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I would willingly go twelue.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Pues ala mano de dios Pedro ten eſſe eſtríbo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Then in the name of God, Peter holde this ſtirrup.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Pedro of Llamáys compañéro?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Friend are you called Peter?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A ſervício de v.m.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: At your ſeruice ſir.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Pues no le hága Dios mas mal a Pedro de el que ſe le alcánça.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Then God do no more miſchiefe to Peter, then that he knowes himſelfe how to practiſe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No ay porque Dios de ſalúd a ſu merçéd.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is no cauſe why God giue you health ſir.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sé que las pullas no ſe han de echár a los amígos.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I know that men ought not to flout their friends.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: ❀ De amígo a amígo chínche en el ójo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: One friend to another friend, a Chinche, a little rounde creature with many feete, in hot countries, breeding in beds, bites worſe then a louſe, and ſtinketh filthily. Cinche in the eie.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yo no quiero pléito con vos Pédro que ſabéis mucho.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I will not go to law with you Peter, for that you know ſo much.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Mas Sabér i. To know. Alſo to ſauor well in taſte, as meate, drinke. Sábe vn torézno.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A raſher of bacon ſauers more.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Moço de mulas vn punto ſáve mas que el diáblo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A mulitter knowes one point more then the diuell.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Pues que penſáis vos que le falta a Pedro para diablo?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Why what thinke you, what wants Peter to become a diuell?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No mas que vn año de aprendiz y vn garaváto.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No more but a yeeres apprentiſhip, and a fleſh-hooke.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Para que el garaváto?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why a fleſh-hooke?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Para ſacár a vueſtras merçédes de la caldéra quando allá váyan.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To pull out your worſhips out of the caulderne when you go thither.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Noſotros no hémos de ýr a el ynfiérno

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: We are not to go to hell.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No ſe yrán mas lleváros hán.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: You are not to go, but they are to carrie you thither.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Are dro váyas malo, ergo maledicte diabole.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Come behinde me therefore euill ſpirit, Maledicte diabole.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Pedro amigo de que ſe haze la puta viéja?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Friend Peter, of what is an old whore made of?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: De la puta móça.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Of a yoong whoore.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No ſe haze ſi no de ſeldo y eneldo y de el cagaxón mordéldo y de el polvo de las éras, hath two ſignifications, one for the floore where they threſh their corne, and alſo thou art. éras.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is not made but of thy ſelfe and the herb dill, & of ſhitting eate thy fill, & of the duſt of barn floore, or of the duſt of which thou art thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: De cara me le véo y tiéne alpargátes, y va a pié.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſee him iuſt ouer againſt me, and he hathShooes of packthred made for footemen or lackeies to trauell a foote. ſhooes of packthred, and hee goes a foote.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Pedro mira que te dize no reſpóndes?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Peter, harke what he ſaith vnto thee, doeſt thou not anſwere?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ No óygo que ſoy ſordo de vna muéla.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I heare not, for I am deafe of one of my chocke teeth.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: ❀ Pues a el maeſtro Cuchilláda?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: What hath the maſter of Fence a blowe or venie?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No me laſtíma mucho eſta Herída que es dáda vñas arríba, peró guarde ſe de el rebés que yo tiraré vñas abájo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: This wound hurts me not much, for it is giuen with the hand vpward, but beware of the ſwaſh blow, for I will draw it with the hand downwards.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Pedro yo entiendo que ſoys vos aquel que Llamávan de vrde malas.

sp.speaker: A.
