sp.p: Peter I vnderſtande that you are hee which they called a plotter of knaueries?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Pues todo el mundo ojo alerta que alguna téngo de vrdír en éſte camíno.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Euery one looke to himſelfe, for I must plot ſomthing this iourney.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Pedro alli viéne vn, caminánte échale vna pulla.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Peter there commeth a traueller, beſtowe a quip on him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ola hermano por donde van?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hola brother, which way go they?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: A do?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: En caſa de la puta que os parió.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: To the houſe of the queane thy mother.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Buena a fee otra a el compañéro que quéda atrás.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Good in faith, another to his companion, which remaines behind.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A ſeñór es ſuyo el mulo?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ho ſir, is the mule yours?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Qual mulo?

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: What mule?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Aquel que beſéis en el cúlo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That whoſe arſe kiſſe you.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Eſte cavalléro que viene muy brábo no baya ſin la ſuya.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: This gentleman which goeth ſo bodily, let him not paſſe without his flout.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A ſenor v.m. a caſo va a londres?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ho ſir goes your worſhip to London?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Si voy porque lo dezís.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.p: Yea, I go for that you ſaie it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Pues cagaxón para quien va a Londres.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Then a turd for him that goeth to London.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Que boníto es Pedro ſi ſe lavaſſe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Oh how proper a man were Peter, if he were waſhed and painted.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Antes deſpues de lavado no valgo nada.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Nay after I am waſhed I am worth nothing.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Quanto avrémos andádo Pedro?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How far haue we iourneyed Peter?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ Nunca buelvo a mirár atrás, por no ſer como la mugér de Lot.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I neuer turne to looke backe, becauſe I would not be as Lots wife.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Quanto nos falta de aqui a el primer Puéblo?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How far haue we from hence to the next towne?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Legua y miérda.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A league and a turd.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: La legua andarémos noſotros, eſotra vos la paſaréis.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The league we will goe, the other thou ſhalt paſſe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Pues por que ſe paſſe ſin ſentír quenta vn quento Pedro.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That we may paſſe ouer this iourney without weariſomnes, tell vs a tale Peter.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: De dinéros para mi le contára yo de buena gana.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: For my part, I would tell money with a better will.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, ſi no algun acaeçído que te avíno por eſſos camínos.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not ſo, but ſome chaunce that hath fallen out to thee on theſe waies.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Eſtonces contár les hé vno que me ſubçedío el viáje paſſádo haziendo eſte camíno con vn hidálgo.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Then I will tell you one which happened vnto me the laſt voyage I came this way with a gentleman.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No ſea muy largo que me dormiré.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Let it not be too long, for I will ſleepe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Siſe durmiére la mohína tendrá cuydádo de deſpertár le.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If you ſleepe, the ſhe mule will be carefull to wake you.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Vos le havéis levantádo mil falſos teſtimónios, mira quan bien camína y quan manſa va?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: You haue raiſed a thouſand falſe teſtimonies againſt her, behold how wel ſhe trauelleth, and how well ſhe goeth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ A el freír lo verá.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A collier ſold coales to a woman and putting downe his coales put vp her frying pan, the woman aſking if they were good coales, he anſwered, A freýr lo verá, i. by the frying ſhe ſhould ſee.By the frying you ſhall ſee.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Ea dexémos eſſo vaya el quento.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well let vs leaue this, forward with the tale.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
Pocos dias ha, yo víne eſte camíno con vno de los mayores habladóres que he conoçido en mi vida y como el hablár mucho, y el mentír ſon tan pariéntes, dezía las mas terríbles mentíras que ſe pueden ymaginár, pues como el me preguntáſſe vn dia que me parecía de ſu buena converſaçión, yo le reſpondí que muy bien, peró que quando contáſſe algun quento, ſe Alargaſſe y paſáſſe tanto, que dava que mormurar a quantos le oýan, el me díxo pues ſea eſta la manera quando llegueemos a las poſádas, ſienta ſe tu apar de mi, y ſi me viéres contár álgo que te parézca que voy fuera de camino, tira me de la halda, eſtonçes yo entenderé, y me deterné, con eſte con çierto llegamos aquella noche a vna venta, donde a caſo avían llegado tanbien muchos cavalléros, y como ſe aſentaſſen a çenár y mi ámo entre ellos, yo me púſe a ſu lado conforme a el conciérto, y como es coſtumbre cada vno començó a contár las maravíllas que avía viſto por el mundo, llegó la bez a el bueno de mi amo el qual dixo que avia eſtado en tierra de japón, y que entre otras coſas maravilloſas que alli avia viſto fue vna yglézia que tenía mil pies de largo, a eſté tiémpo yo que le
vide yr tan deſmandádo y como eſtava a lerta tíro le rézio de la halda, el luego me entendió, y díxo; y vno en ancho: los cavalleros ſe començáron a mirár vnos a otros y a ſon-reýr ſe háſta que vno dellos díxo, vala me Dios ſeñór, y para que ſervía eſſa y glézia tan larga y angoſta, de mill pies de largo? y vno en ancho, el replicó agradez can vueſtras mer çedes que me tiráron de la falda atiempo, que ſi no, yo les boto a Dios que yo la quadrára, fue eſtonçes tanta la riſa de todos que a mi amo le convino aquella noche ſalirſe de la venta, por que entre todos quedó por refrán quando alguno contáva algo que pareçia mentira ❀ Le dezia el terçero quadre la v. m. que harto larga eſtá.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p:
A little while ſince, I came this way with one of the greateſt babblers that I knew in my life, and as much prating and lying are neere of kinne, hee tolde the most horrible lies that could be imagined, afterward as he asked me one daie, what I thought of his good behauiour, I made him anſwere, that I thought well, but that when hee did tell any tale, hee paſſed the bounds ſo much, that he gaue occaſion to as many as did heare him, to ſpeake ill of him behinde his backe: he tolde me, ſeeing it is ſo, when we come to our Innes, ſit thou next vnto me, and if thou ſhalt ſee me tell any thing that ſeemes vnto thee that I goe out of the way, pluck me by the skirt, then will I vnderſtand and ſtay my ſelfe, with this agreement we came that night to a lodging on the high waie, whither by chaunce alſo many gentlemen were arriued, and as they ſate them downe to ſupper, and my maſter among them, I ſet my ſelfe cloſe by his ſide, according to our agreement, and as the manner is, euery one began to tell of the maruels which hee had ſeene in the world, the turne came to the good man my maſter, who ſaide that hee had beene in the lande of Iaptha, and among other mauellous things that there he had ſeene was a church, which was a thouſand foote
long: then I ſeeing him ſo far out of order, as I was readie prepared, pluckt him by the skirt, he preſently vnderſtood me, and ſaid; and one foot in breadth: the gentlemen began to looke one vpon another, and to ſmile, vntill one of them ſaide, In the name of God ſir, and for what vſe ſerued this church ſo long & narrow, of a thouſand foot in length, and but one in breadth? he replied, thanke him, that pulled me by the skirt of the garment ſo ſoone, which if he had not done, I vow to God, I had made it fower ſquare: then was there ſuch a laughter among all, that my maſter was faine that night to get him out of the Inne, for that among them all, it remained as a prouerbe, when any one did tell any thing which did ſeeme a lie, the third man ſaid vnto him, make it ſquare, for it is long enough.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: De vna coſa me eſpanto yo Pedro.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Of one thing I woonder Peter.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Qual es?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Como pudíſte durár tan largo tiempo con tu competidor en la facultád.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How thou couldest endure ſo long time, with thy competitor in thine owne facultie?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: ❀ Si, por que eſſe es tu enemígo el que es de tu ofiçio.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea, for he is thy enimie which is of thy owne profeſſion.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Es verdád que muchas vezes le quí ſe dexár por eſſo, y ſe lo dezía que no quería mas caminár con el, por que era tocádo de mi própria enfermedád y no me dexava hazér báſa.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It is true, for many times I would leaue him for this cauſe, and did tel him, that I would not trauell no more with him, becauſe he was infected with my diſeaſe, and did not ſuffer me to take vpAs at cards. a tr • cke.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Y que reſpondió a éſſo?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: And what anſwere made he to this?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Luego me prometía con juraménto, que callaría tóda vna jornada para que yo habláſſe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Foorthwith he promiſed me with an oth, that he woulde hold his peace all one iourney, that I might ſpeake.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Y cumplía lo?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: And did he performe it?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Tan ynpoſible le éra a el podér lo ❀ cumplír cómo a v. m. dijerír eſſe pelo de aſno, queha comido.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: It was as impoſſible for him to haue power to accompliſh it, as for your worſhip to digest thisi. Calling him aſſe by craft or the gudgeons, or fooleries to day you haue ſwallowed. aſſes haire which you haue eaten.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Compañero pagado os han vueſtro travájo.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Companion, you are paid home for your labour.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No tenéis razon Pedro anſiyo os vea zarco a podér de núbes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You miſtake Peter, I ſee you dimne ſighted, by reaſon of cloudes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Antes ciegue, que mal véa.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Rather wiſh I you blinde, then that I ſee ill.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
❀ Anſi yo os vea arçobíſpo con mitra
de ſiéte palmas.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Nay rather that I may haue my ſight
to ſee you an Archbiſhop withi. Caróça, which is a high hat of paper ſet on the head of a bawde, riding on an aſſe thorow the ſtreetes for a puniſhment. a miter of ſeuen hand bredths high.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Anſi yo le véa a el, Pápa higos de ſu múla.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Nay not ſo, but that I might alſo ſee you eat the ſhittings of your mule.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: ❀ Echo te vna pulla Pulla a flout. con ſu pullonçillo que tu mugér te haga çiérvo y te llámen tódos cuquíllo.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cast thee a bone, with his yong one to gnawe vpon, thy wife makes thee a hart, and they call thee cuckolde euery one.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ Echo te vna pulla venida ſobre mar, que los dientes ſe te cáygan y no puedas meár.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I cast the bone to gnaw vpon at ſea, thy teeth fall out, and thy water hold in.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Piquémos compañéro que ſe va haziendo tarde.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Let vs ſpurre on companion, for it waxeth late.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Que hora ſerá Pedro?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What is it a clocke Peter?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: La de ayer a eſtas oras puntualménte.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Iuſt the ſame, as it was yeſterday at this time.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Eſſo tanbien lo dixéra mi mula ſi ſupiéra hablár.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: This could my mule tell me, if ſhe could ſpeake?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Soy yo Relóx, que me pregúnta que óra es?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Am I a clocke, that you aske me what it is a clocke?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: ❀ A lo menos Badájo, a clapper of a bell by a metaphor a ioulthead. badájo, que monta tanto.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: At least thou art a clapper, which is all one.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Y ſi doy adonde daré?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: And if I do ſtrike where ſhall I hit?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: En la cabeça de el puto de tu padre.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Vpon the head of the buggerer thy father.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Mas çerca eſtá la ſuya y ſonará bien, pues eſta huéca.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Your head is neere vnto me, and it will ſound well ſeeing it is hollow.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Bien camina de andadúra vueſtra mula.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Your mule doth go a ſwift eaſie paſe.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yla vueſtra ha bien deportánte.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: And yours ambles well.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Si no la convirtiéſſe algunas vezes en tróte que pareçe a el de la madre.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: If ſhe did not change it, ſometimes into a trot, which ſeemes like the trot of hir dam.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Entrémos en eſta vénta a dár çevada y comér vn vocádo.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Let vs go in into this Inne, to baite and eate a bitte.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Vn bocádo no mas, mas piénſo yo comér de vn çiento.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What one bit and no more, I thinke to eate more then a hundred.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: No os ſabréis paſſár un dia ſin comér Pedro?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Can you not paſſe one daie Peter without eating?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ Par dios nuéſtro amo, como díze el viz caíno, trípas llévan a pies que no pies a trípas.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: By God our maſter as theA Biskaine trauelling a foote fainte for want of foode, filled his belly, afterward went luſtely, & ſaid, the belly carrieth the feete, & not the feete the bellie. Biskaine ſaith, the bellie carrieth the feete and not the feete the bellie.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: ❀ Yo tambien digo que pan y víno ánden camíno que no moço garrído.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I alſo ſay,The lustie youth without eating or drinking must needs faint, and giue him that, although he be faint he goeth forward. that bread and wine are trauellers, and not the lustie frolike youth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Paz ſea en éſta caſa quien eſtá acá huéſpeda?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Peace be in this houſe, who is heere hosteſſe?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Quien eſtá alla quien lláma?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Who is there, who cals?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ay poſáda ſeñora?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Haue you lodging mistris?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Si ſeñór, éntren y ſéan muy bien venídos que todo recádo ay.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Yes Sir, come in, and be very well welcome, for all good entertainment is here to be had.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Que aurá que comér?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What ſhall we haue to dinner?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Ay conéjos ay perdíçes, ay pollos, ay gallinas, ay ganços, ay ánades, ay carnero, ay vaca, ay cabrito, ay menudo de puerco.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: There are conies, there are partridges, there are chickens, hennes, geeſe, ducks, there is mutton, there is beefe, kid, and hogs inwards.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bien dixe yo que en ſu caſa de v.m. no podia faltár puerco.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Well ſaide I, that in your houſe there could not want hogs fleſh.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Ni en la ſuya faltará vellaco, mientras el eſtuviére dentro.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Nor in your houſe ſhall there want a knaue while you are within.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No en verdád ſeñora, ſi no que me dixéron que los diás paſſádos avía v.m. reñido bravaménte con la limpiéça.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No in truth mistris, but they told me that a while agoe you and cleanlines had been at bate.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Tambien me dixeron a mi que avía el deſterrádo la Verguença de ſu caſa.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: And they told me, that you had baniſhed ſhamefastnes from your houſe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Huelgo me Pedro que as topado con lo que avías meneſtér.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I am glad Peter that thou haſt mette with that thou haddeſt need of.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yaun ella me ha meneſtér a mi.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: And alſo ſhe hath need of me.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: ❀ Yo por çierto, ſi no es para poner le en peralvillo con doze y la maeſtra, no ſe para que?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I haue neede of him truly, if it be but to put him in Peralvíllo, a mount in Spaine where they ſhoote malefactors to death. Peralvillo to ſhoote twelue arrowes at him with thei. That arrow which hitteth on the hart. miſtris, I know not for what els?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Aora Señóra no nos digámos mas calláte, y callémos que ſendas nos tenemos.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Now miſtris, let vs ſaie no more, holde your peace and let vs be ſtill, for we haue a quip a peece.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Ea acábe habladór de Ventája, pida lo que ha meneſtér.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Go to, make an end babbler in graine, & demand that you haue need of.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Deme héno, y paja, y çebáda, para las mulas.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Giue me haie, and ſtraw, and prouender for the mules.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Quanto quiere?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: How much will you haue?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Dos harnéros de héno y un zelemín de çebáda.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Two ſieues full of haie, and a pecke of barley.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Muy poco es para tres véſtias.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: It is very little for three beaſtes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Aquí no ay mas que dos qual es la ótra?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Heere are no more then two, which is the other?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: La otra ſóys vos y mas tragóna que eſſótras dos.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: The other are you, and more deuouring then the other two.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Si ſoy mas, no de paxa ni çebada porque es muy dúra de digeſtión.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: If I be more, it is not of ſtraw nor barley, for it is very hard of digeſtion.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Mas duro es vn garróte y ſuele ablandár las coſtíllas a vn velláco.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Harder is a cudgell, and yet it vſeth to ſoften the ribs of a knaue.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Bien eſtá no paſſe mas adelante ſeñora Huéſpeda quanto pónen de aquí a la çiudád?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: It is well, paſſe no further forward miſtreſſe hosteſſe, how far doe they count it from hence to the citie?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Señor çinco leguas.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Sir fiue leagues.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Podrémos los caminár de a quia la noche?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: May we ride them betwixt this and night?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Como picáren?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: As you ſhal hasten.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Ay algun río en el camíno o algun mal paſſo?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Is there any riuer in the way, or any euill paſſage?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Por do quiera, ay vna legua de mal camíno.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Which way ſoeuer you goe, there is a league of euill waie.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Ay adonde herrár?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Is there any placeTo miſſe or erre. Alſo to ſhooe a horſe or mule. herrár?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: El camino no ſeñór, las mulas ſi ſeñor, vuéſtras merçédes mil partes ay donde pueden herrár.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: The way, no Sir, the mules, yes Sir, a thouſand paſſages where you may erre.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: ❀ Si ſon los yerros por amores, dignos ſon de perdonár.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: If they be errors for loue, they are worthie to be pardoned.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Señora huéſpeda cuya es éſta venta?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Miſtreſſe hosteſſe, whoſe is this inne?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: De vn cavallero de la çiudád.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: A gentlemans of the citie.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Quanto págan por ella de arrendamiénto en vn año?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: How much doe you pay for the hire of it by the yeere?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Mas que ella vale, quinientos ducados.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: More then it is woorth, fiue hundred ducats.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: De eſſa ſuerte, buena maña ſe an meneſtér dar a hurtár para ſa cár la coſta.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: By this meanes they had neede good skill to ſteale to get out their charge.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Eſſa no fálta, el gáto por liebre, la carne de mula por váca, el víno paſsádo por água todo va de éſta manera.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: That skill wants not, a cat for hare fleſh, the fleſh of a mule for beefe, wine mixed with water, all goes in this manner.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: ❀ Mala paſqua de Dios a el vellaco y mal ſan Iuán. quando ha viſto el, eſſo en mi venta?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: God ſend the knaue an ill Eaſter, and an ill Midſommer, when haue you ſeene this in my Inne?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Viſto lo no, guſtádo lo ſi.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: I haue not ſeene, but I haue taſted it?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Vos mentis como velláco, que nunca tal.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: You lie like a knaue, there was neuer any ſuch matter.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ Aora eſtémos a quenta huéſpeda no demos de comér a el Diablo, venga acá no ſe acherda el otro día quando yo vine por aquí con un cavallero, que le pidió le dieſſe un pedáço de carne de aquéllo que le avía dádo otro dia antes quando avía paſsádo por aquí, porque dezía que le avía ſavído muy bien, lo qual oyendo aquel niño chiquíto, díxo caro nos coſtaría, ſi cada dia ſe nos avía de morír un Roçín.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hosteſſe we are vpon the reckoning now,Let vs not braule and fall out, and ſo go to law vpon words and ſo make the diuell dine. let vs not giue the diuell his dinner, come hither, doe you not remember the other daie, when I came this way with a gentleman which requeſted you to giue him a peece of meate, of that you had giuen him the other day before, when he paſſed this waie, bicauſe he ſaid it liked his taſte very well, the which the little childe hearing, ſaide, it would be deare fleſh vnto vs, if euery day there ſhoulde die a nagge.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Es Verdád que aquello fue aquel Roçín que ſe nos murió, peró eſtáva tan górdo y tan líndo que éra mejór que carne de váca.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: It is true, that there was a nagge which died, but hee was ſo fat and ſo faire, that hee was better then beefe.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Señóra huéſpeda aunque mas líndo ſea, no nos dee de el agóra.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Mistres hosteſſe, although he might be more fine, giue vs not of that nowe.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: No Señór que ya ſe acabó, haſta aora avia de durár?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: No ſir, for he is already made an end of, what think you it could laſt til now?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Veámos el víno que tal es.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Let vs ſee the wine that is ſo good.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: El vino es tal, que báſta a llevár al cielo a el, que acoſtumbráre a bevér lo.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: The wine is ſuch, that it is ſufficient to bring a man to heauen that ſhall vſe to drinke it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ola nueſtra áma no baſta ventéra ſi no eréje?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: What now Mistreſſe, is it not ynough to be a keeper of an Inne, except you be an heretike too?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Lo que yo dígo es verdád y lo provaré que el buen víno, lleva los hombres a el çielo.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: That which I ſay is true, and I will prooue it, that good wine carrieth men vp to heauen.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: De que manera?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Elbuen vino cría buena ſangre, la buena ſangre engéndra buena condición, la buena condiçión pára buenas óbras, las buenas obras, llévan a los hombres a el cielo.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Good wine makes good blood▪ good blood doth engender good condition, good condition doth ende in good works, good works carrie men to heauen.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Ella ha aprovado ſu yntención baſtanteménte.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: She hath prooued her intent very ſufficiently.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Peró no ſe podrá dezír eſſo por éſte víno.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But this cannot bee verified in this wine.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Por que?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: ❀ Por que eſto mas paréçe vinágre y água.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Becauſe this ſeemes rather vineger and water.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Agua, no por vida de mi ánima, que tiene mas de la, que le echo el de lo alto.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Water, by the life of my ſoule, it hath no more water in it, then he from aboue put in it.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Pues Dios no le vino a echár água, que ſin agua lo crio.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: God neuer came to put water into wine, but without water he created it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Bien, no eſtá v.m. en el quénto, el de lo alto es ſu marído, que eſtá en lo alto de la caſa, y deſde allí, écha água en el vino, por una cebratána.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Well, you vnderſtand not the matter a right. He from aboue is hir huſband, which is in the top of the houſe, and from thence puts water into the wine with a long tunnell.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Con vos me entiérren Pedro que ſabéys de quenta.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I will die and liue with thee Peter, for thou knoweſt faſhions.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Yo entendía que llamáva a Dios, el de lo alto.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: I vnderſtoode that ſhe had called God, him that was from aboue.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: En todas las coſas ay engáño.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In euery thing there is deceit.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Si no es en la ropa vieja.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Except it be in an old garment.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Por ciérto que tienen razón, que eſtá ya el mundo muy perdído, por eſſo nos hémos recogído mi marído y yo a éſta vénta, por acabár en buena vida.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Truely they haue reaſon, for the worlde is very badde, for this cauſe haue my husbande and I withdrawen our ſelues into this Inne to make an end in good life.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Eſta llamáys buena vida huéſpeda?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Call you this a good life hoſteſſe?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Si Señór, que peor éra la de los de Sodóma y Gomórra.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Yea ſir, for that of Sodom and Gomorra was woorſe.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: No le paréçe a v.m. que es buena vida eſtár hechos hermitaños en eſte disyerto, que mas hiziéron los padres de el yermo?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Do you not thinke that it is a good life to be made Hermites in this deſart, what did the fathers in the wildernes more then this?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Y tan virtuóſos, que de limóſna, a quantos paſſan les quítan lo que llévan.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: And ſo holie that of pure almes, of, as many as paſſe they take away that they carie.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Quitár, nunca Dios tal quiera, reçebír lo que nos dan con cortesía, eſſo ſi.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Take away, God forbid, receiue that they giue vs with curteſie that we doe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Es el cáſo, que llaman cortesía a la gançúa, con que ábren las viçáças.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Thus it is, they call the picklocke curteſie, with which they open the mailes.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: El diablo trúxo a éſte moço a mi caſa, vete con todos los diáblos, eſpíritu de contradiçión.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: The diuell brought this ſeruant to my houſe, get thee hence in the diuels name, thou ſpirit of contradiction.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ Mal me quieren mis comádres, por que les dígo las verdádes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: My goſſips cannot abide me, becauſe I ſpeake truth vnto them truely.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Aóra Pedro, haze quenta con la huéſpeda, y vamos de aquí, que es tarde.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Now Peter reckon with the hosteſſe and let vs begon hence, for it is late.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Que ſe deve de todo huéſpeda?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hosteſſe what is owing in the whole?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Eſpéreſe, contaré, dos de paja, y de paja dos, tres de çebada, çinco de víno, vno de carne y dos de toçíno, veynte reales entodo.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Tarie I little, I will reckon, two of ſtraw, and of ſtraw two, three of barley, fiue of wine, one of fleſh, and two of bacon, ten ſhillings in the whole.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ Quénta hecha, mula muerta, eſcudéro ýos a pie, pues a mi me quiére dar papilla ſeñora huéſpeda, ❀ no ſave, que quando élla naçió, ya yo comía pan con cortéça: eſpére haré yo la mia.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The reckoning made, the mule dead, ſeruing man get your way a foote why the miſtreſſe hoſteſſe will giue me pap, doth ſhe not knowe, that when ſhe was borne, then did I eat bread with hard crust, tarrie ile make my reckoning.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Haze, veámos.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Make it, let vs ſee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ Tres y dos ſon çinco, dos de blanco y tres de tinto, y otros tres de eſtópas y pez, vno de la ólla y dos de la chólla, y médio de la çebólla, ochoſon en todos.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Three and two are ſiue, two of ſacke & three of wine ſomewhat blacke, and other three of the hurdes of flaxe and pitch, one of the pot, and two of theThe hinder part of the head nowle, and a halfe of the chibbowle, they are eight in the whole.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Malos años para vos, págame aquí, ſi no, por el ſiglo de mi padre que os arañe éſſa cára.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: What with a miſchiefe to you, paie mee heere; if not, by my fathers ſoule ile put out thine eies.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ Quitádo ſe ha el gáto la rópa de la ypocrasía, ſeñóra hermitáña, tenga paciénçia y no tanta codícia.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The cat hath cast off theThe cat faining hir ſelfe a Hermite, put on a Hermits weed and many beaſts and creatures came to hir for ghostly counſell, at last came the mice, which when ſhe ſpied, flong off the garment and to them. garment of hypocriſie, miſtris Hermite haue patience, and be not ſo couetous.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: ❀ No me quente mortuórios, ſi no pagué me, ſi no, las bárbas le ſacaré vna a vna.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Do not reckon vp mortuaries vnto me, but paie me, if not I will pull off the haires of thy beard one by one.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Da le, lo que pidiére, la huéſpeda Pedro no riñas con ella.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Giue that which the Hosteſſe doth require Peter & braul not with hir.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: En vna náo cargáda de plata, no ay hárto para contentárla.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: In a ſhip loaden with ſiluer there is not enough to content hir.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p:
No pído ſi no lo juſto, paga me hermáno
y déxate de palabras.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
I require nothing but my right, pay me
brother and leaue of words.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Anſi dize la picáza, tome ſeñóra ve ay dóze reáles, los ſeis ſon de buéno, y los ſeis de mal provécho le hágan.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: So ſaith theAll in one ſong. chattering Pie, holde mistres, ſee heere ſixe ſhillings, three of them be much good doe it you with them, and the other three the diuell choake you with them.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Mas no, ſi no los ſeis, ſon de bien venídos ſéan, y los ſeys de en óra mala váys.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Not ſo, but the one three are of welcome vnto me, and the other three the diuell go with thee.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ Maldiciónes de putas viéjas, oraçiónes ſon de ſalúd.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Curſinges of old whoores are praiers of health.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Quéde ſe con Dios Señora huéſpeda.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: God be with you mistres Hoſteſſe.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: El váya con vueſtras merçédes, aqui eſtá éſta pobre poſáda para todas las vézes que viniéren eſte camíno, les ſuplico ſe ſirvan délla.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: God conduct your worſhips, heere is this poore Inne, for as often as you ſhall come this way, I entreate you to vſe it at your command.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: ❀ Sobre buen haz de pája tía.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: i. Their money.Aunt you do it vpon a good ſheafe of ſtrawe.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: No, ſino por ſus ojos bellídos lo harán.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: No, but onely for your faire lookes ſir.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Quede con dios tía, y el la hága buena hermitáña.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Aunt God be with you, and make you a good hermite.

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: Anda con dios híjo, y el os hága me jór de lo que ſoys.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Farewell ſonne, and God make thee better then that thou art.

row.cell: Diálogo quinto, entre tres Pájes, llamados el uno Iuan, el otro Franciſco, el otro Guzman, en el qual ſe contienen, las ordinárias plàticas que los pájes ſuelen tenér unos con otros.
The fift Dialogue betweene three Pages, called the one of them Iohn, the other Frances, the other Guzman, wherein are conteined the ordinarie ſpeeches which pages are wont to haue one with the other.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: DE donde viénes Franciſco?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: FRom whence come you Frances?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: De la corte Iuan.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: From the court Iohn.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Que ay por allá de nuevo?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: What is the newes there?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: El rollo ſe eſtá adonde ſolía, el Rey ha mandádo que quien tuviére que comér, que cóme, y el otro que ayúne.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: The gallowes is where it was wont to be, the king hath commanded that hee that hath any thing to dinner, that he eate it, and he that hath not that he fast.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Viſte a la Réyna?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Haue you ſeene the Queene?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Ala de diamantes con que híze el poſtrer flux.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: The Queene of Diamonds with which I made the laſt fluſh.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Luego jugado has?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Haſt thou now beene at gaming?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Yo no, mis dineros jugáron al trocádo, y trocáron me por otro dueño.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Not I, my money plaied at exchange, and changed me for another maſter.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Ganáſte o perdíſte?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Hast thou won or lost?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Gané y perdí.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I haue woon and I haue lost.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Como púdo sér?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: How could that be?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Perdí mis dinéros, y gané eſcarmiénto para no jugár mas.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I lost my money, and got a warning to play no more.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: No ſería pérdida la del dinero, ſi tu llevaſſes adelante eſſe propóſito, peró yo dígo, que quien hízo, hará.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: The loſſe of money ſhould be no loſſe, if thou didst go forward in this purpoſe, but I ſay, that he that hath once plaied will play againe.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: A lo menos mientras me durare el Eſcozór, no jugaré mas.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: At the least, while the ſmarting ſhall last I will play no more.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Eſſe no te durare mas que haſta llegár de aquí a tu caſa, o haſta que tengas mas dinéros.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: That will not last with thee longer, then till thou commest home, or vntill thou hast more money.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Pues yo para que quiero el dinero, tengo de comprár caſas, o viñas con ello.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What ſhould I doe with money, am I to buy houſes or vinyards with it?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Para embiár a tus pariéntes, o para luzírte con ello.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: To ſend it to thy friends and kinred, or to make thy ſelfe trim with it.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Luzírme o que? malos años, Lúzgame el puto de mi ámo pues ſe ſirve de mi.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: To make my ſelfe trim? a plague take it, let the buggerer my master trim me ſeeing he ſerues himſelfe of me.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Pues pienſas que te ha de durár tu ámo toda la vída?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Why thinkest thou thy master is to liue with thee for euer?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Dure lo que duráre, como cuchár de pan, que quando éſte me falte, no faltará otro tan ruyn como el.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Let him last as long as a ſpoone of bread, when he is wanting to me, there will not faile another as bad as hee.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Y quando ſéas grande?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: And when thou art better growen in yeeres?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Eſtonces ya ſabémos el paradéro de los pajes, o ala guérra, o a un monaſtério, o a la hórca.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Then we know the end of Pages, either to the warre, or to a monasterie, or to the gallowes.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Eſſo poſtrero lo le renuncio en ti.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: This last I leaue to thee.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Pues penſais vos eſca páros por y pócrita?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why thinke you to ſcape becauſe you are an Hypocrite?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Hermáno, en mi lináje nunca úvo ningun ahorcádo, no quiero eſtrenárlo yo.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Brother, in my kinred neuer was there any hanged, I will not hanſell the gallowes.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Eſtrenada os darán la ſoga, no os penſeys por eſſo.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: They will giue you a halter for hanſell, take you no care for that.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Pienſa el ladrón que todós ſon de ſu condición, yo hermano no piénſo hazér obras por donde la meréſca.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Well thinkes the theefe, that all are as himſelfe, I brother do not thinke to doe any thing that I may deſerue the gallowes.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Pues no as oýdo dezír, que el penſár no es ſabér, eſſo ſin penſár ſe verná antes que vn colongía.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But hast thou not heard ſaie, that opinion is no knowledge, this without thinking will come ſooner then a canonſhip.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
Yo bien c réo, que ſi yo trato mucho contígo, que tu me procurerás pegár la tiña, porque vn
puerco encenagádo, ſiempre procúra encenagár a ótro.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
I well beleeue, that if I deale much with thee, thou wilt infect me with mangines, for one hog that hath
wallowed in the mire will beray another.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Dizes verdád, que fi el ladrón anda con el hermitáño, o el ladrón ſerá hermitaño, o el hermitaño ladrón, peró tu nunca juegas?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Thou ſayest true, for if a theefe keepe companie with a hermit, either a theefe ſhall become a hermit, or a hermit a theefe, but dost thou neuer play?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Yo no en mi vída.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I, neuer in my life.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Pues tente bien no cáygas, porque a fee que ſi cáes, que as de ſer como los borráchos que comiençan tarde a ſer lo, que por eſquitárſe de lo que han dexádo de bevér, nunca ſalen de cueros.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Then hold fast, fall not, for in faith if thou fallest, thou art like to be as drunken men, which beginne at length ſo to be, which to quit themſelues of that they haue left to drinke, they neuer get out of drunkennes.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Si Dios me guarde mi júyzio, yo me guardaré deſſe vicio.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: If God keepe me in my right minde, I wil keepe my ſelfe from this vice.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Mas fuerte éra Tróya, y fue deſtruyda.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Troy was more ſtrong, and yet was ouercome.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Dexémos éſſo agóra, y díme como te va con tu ámo?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Let vs leaue this now, and tell me how your maſter and you agree?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: A mi muy bien, porque como es moço, galán, y enamorádo, ſon tres coſas que ſácan de harón al mas cuerdo, y anſi todo ſe nos va en fieſtas, vna libréa oy, ótra mañána, ſiempre en ſaráos, múſicas, y dánças, ſiempre en combites, que mal año para Lançarote quando de Bretaña víno, ſi éra tan bien tratádo como noſotros.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I like very well of him, for he is yoong, gallant, and in loue, they are three things which buſie the wiſest man, & ſo we are altogither in feaſtings, one liuery to day, another to morrow, neuer without good cheere, muſicke, daunces, and banquets, that the diuell take Lançarote when he came from Brittaine if he were ſo well entreated as we are.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Si peró a fée que créo, que tras buen bocádo, dais buen grito.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Yea, but in faith I beleeue that after a good morſell, you paie well for it.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Porque dízes éſſo?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why ſaieſt thou ſo?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Porque me parece que ſi vueſtro ámo dánça de la manera, voſotros no avéys d'eſtár ocióſos, ſino que avéys de çapateár, porque en caſa del múſico, todos los criádos ſon dançántes.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: For I thinke, that if your maſter daunce in ſuch ſort, you are not altogether idle, but that you foote it too, for in a muſitions houſe all the ſeruants are dauncers.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Es verdád que eſſo a coſadíllos, nos trae de dia con recaudos, y de noche con rondas, peró con el buen peſebre, todo ſe paſſa y no como tu que eſtás ſerviéndo a vn pelón, que te deve matár de hambre.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: It is true, that by reaſon of this loue ſmall occaſions driue vs in the day time with letters, and in the night we round the ſtreet, but with good fare we paſſe ouer all this, and not as thou dost which ſeruest a miſerable wretch, which killeth thee with hunger.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: No mata, porque yo nunca túve vida, deſpues que eſtoy con el.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: He kils me not, for I neuer had life ſince I came to him.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: No tiéne buen ordinário?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Hath he not a good ordinarie table?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: La lazéria es ordinaria en cáſa.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Wretchedneſſe it ſelfe is his ordinarie prouiſion in houſe.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Que os da a comér?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What diet doth he giue you?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Eſperanças y folias.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Hopes and ſongs.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Con éſſo eſtás tan gordo?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: And with this art thou ſo fat?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: De los Tovillos ſi eſtoy.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: If I be fat, it is in my ankle bones.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Dalle cantonáda.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Run away from him.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Temo de encontrár otro peór, y no querría por huýr de la llama dár en las bráſas.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I am afraid to meete with a woorſe, and I would not leape out of the frying pan, and fall into the fire.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Haz te cuchillo de melonéro, provár muchos haſta hallár uno buéno.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Make of thy ſelfe a knife to cut pumpions, prooue many vntill you finde one good.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Luégo cobra hombre mala fama, y le ❀ dízen Piédra movedíza no la cobre móho, y todo el mundo le da del cobdo.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Straightway a man gets an ill name, and they ſay a rolling ſtone gathereth no moſſe, and euery one iuſtleth him a ſide.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: No ſino dexáos ſecár como palo en ſarmentéra.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: No but ſuffer your ſelfe to drie as ſtickes on a pile or heape.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Adonde vas tu agóra?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Whither goeſt thou now?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: A buſcár mi ámo, y témo que no le tengo de podér hallár.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: To ſeeke my master, and I feare that I ſhall not finde him.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Adonde le perdiſte?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Where didſt thou loſe him?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Yo no le perdí, el ſe perdió muchas dias ha.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I lost him not, he lost himſelfe a great while agoe.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Anſi yrá un perdído a buſcár otro perdído, como un duelo búſca otro duélo, y una necedád a otra, porque Pares cum paribus facillimè congregantur.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: So one that is lost himſelfe, goeth to ſeeke another that is lost, as one greefe ſeekes another greefe, and one folly another: for like will to like.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Bendito ſea Dios, que por tres blancas de gramática que ſtudió, ya no ſe cabe en el cuérpo, y no vée la ora que deſembuchár lo.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: God be bleſſed, that forA blancke halfe a Maravedí, a Maravedí 34. of them to ſixe pence. three blanckes of Grammar which he hath ſtudied, now he cannot keepe it in his belly, and he thinkes euerie hower ten, till he hath vttered his whole minde.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Dígo hermano que cada obéja con ſu paréja, y vn ſemijante buſca a ótro.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I ſay brother, euerie ſheepe with his equall, and like will to like.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Anſi tu ámo como es miſeráble pelón, buſca vn ypócrita como tu, a quien con dezílle que es meneſtér ayunár para yr al ciélo, te tiene en diéta perpétua, y canoníza por virtúd, lo que es miſéria fina.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: So thy maſter as he is a miſerable wretch ſeeks out an hypocrite like thy ſelfe, and by telling thee how requiſite it is to faſt for the winning of heauen doth holde thee in continuall diet, and extols that for a vertue, which is pure miſerablenes.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: No tienes razón, que el no es avariénto, peró como dízen Pobréza no es viléza.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: You ſaie not well, for he is not couetous, but as it is ſaide, Pouertie is not vilenes.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: No, mas es maeſtra que enſeña como ſe ha de hazér.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: No, but it is a miſtris which doth teach vs how we ſhould become nigardly.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
Yo ſe, que ſi mi ámo tuviére la rénta
del tuyo que gaſtára mas que el, lo qual el nos díze que hará muy complidaménte ſi dios le mejóra d'eſtádo.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
I know, if my maſter had reu • nues as thy
maſter hath, that hee would ſpend more then he doth, which hee telleth vs he will performe with the beſt, if it pleaſe God to better his eſtate.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: De manéra que éſſas ſon las eſperánças que coméis.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: So then theſe bee the hopes which you feede on.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Mas vale que agua, como dezía la véja que mojáva el ſarmiénto en el río y le chupáva.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: It is better then water, as the olde woman ſaide, which dipped a dry ſticke in the riuer and ſucked it.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Con eſſa comída no dubdo dexéis de ſalír buénos girifáltes al cabo del año.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: With this diet I doubt not but at the yeeres end you may prooue goodi. With this diet you may be light enough to flie. Gerfalcons to flie.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Si peró, ſi bolamos tan alto, llevárnos ha el viento, como haze a todos los que ſe ſuſténtan de ſemejánte manjár.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Yea but if we flie ſo high, the winde will carie vs away, as it doth all thoſe which do feede on ſuch diet.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Por vida de tu madre, que renta tiéne tu ámo?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: By the life of thy mother, what reuenewe hath thy maſter?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Yo te lo diré vn quento de mentíras, y otro de neceſſidádes, y vn millón de necedádes, y todo éſto ſe gaſta cada año, de ſuerte, que viéne a ſalír a rata por cantidád.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I will tell thee, a thouſand thouſandes of lies, and another of needs, a million of fooleries, and all this is ſpent euery yeere in ſuch ſort, that hee ſpends as much as comes in to him.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Quantos cavállos tiene?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: How many horſes hath he?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Dize que cinco con quatro que ſe le an muerto.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: He ſaith fiue, with thoſe fower which are dead.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Quantos críados?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: How many ſeruants?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Nones ſon, y no llégan a tres.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: They are odde, and yet they mount not to three.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: De ſuerte que tu ſolo le ſirves.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: So then thou alone ſerueſt him.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Y aun me podrían açotár por vagamúndo.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: i. In going vp and downe ſhifting for my ſelf, and not liuing on my maſter. And yet might they whip me for a vagabond.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Pues como ſiendo ſolo, no tiénes mucho en que entendér.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: How ſo, ſeeing thou art alone thou hast not much to imploy thy ſelfe on.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Si tengo, en contár láſtimas y calamidádes.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: But I haue much to do to reckon greefes and calamities.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Quando tiempo ha que bives con el?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: How long hast thou liued with him?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Que muéro con el muchos dias ha.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I haue beeni. of hunger. dying with him long ſince.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Hermáno hermáno, quien ſi mude Dios le ayude.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Brother, brother, Godwil him helpe, that ſeekes for it himſelfe.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Si, mas adonde yrá el buey que no áre, por donde quiera veo cien leguas de mal camíno.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Yea, but where ſhall the oxe goe that he ſhall not labour, which way ſoeuer I ſee a hundred leagues of ill way.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Aquí viene Guzmanillo, veámos que nuevas trae, a Guzman que ay de nuevo?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Heere comes little Guzman, let vs ſee what newes hee brings. Hoe Guzman what newes?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
Muchas coſas, el Turco (dizen que) ſe ha tornado Moro, que Venécia nada en agua, y que Ytália eſtá llena de hombres, que en Fráncia
ay mas de cien mil hombres de guerra, y tambien ſe dize de ſecreto que el conde de Flandes a dormido con la Reyna de Eſpaña.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
Many things, the Turke (as they ſay) is become a Moore or infidell,i. Stands built vpon the ſea, the ſea compaſſing it round about. Venice ſwims in water, & Italie is full of people, and that in France
there are more then a hundred thouſand men of armes, and alſo they ſay in ſecret, that theThe king of Spaine in his title Earle of Flaunders. Earle of Flaunders hath lien with the Queene of Spaine.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Todo eſſo ay de nuevo?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Is there all this newes?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Aora viniéron con eſte corréo éſtas nuévas.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Theſe newes came now with this poſte.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: De luengas vías luengas mentíras ſuelen venír.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Farre fetched lies come from farre.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Lo que yo os he dícho, todo estan verdád, como ſer aora de día.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: That which I haue told you is as true as it is now day light.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Luego grandes guérras ſe aparéjan éſte veráno.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Then great warres are like to bee this ſommer.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Los pronóſticos dízen, quéſte veráno los que biviéren, verán grandes maravíllas.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: The Prognostications ſay, thoſe that ſhall liue this ſommer ſhall ſee great woonders.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Que maravíllas ſerán, cuenta nos las.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What ſhall thoſe woonders be, I pray thee tell them vs.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Dízen que el ſol ſerá mayór que toda la tiérra.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: They ſay the ſun ſhall be bigger then all the earth.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Santo Dios, y eſſo ha de sér verdád?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Bleſſed God, and will this prooue true?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Y que la lúna cada noche aparéce de ſu manéra, que las eſtrellas ſino fueſſe por el ſol no ternán reſplandór ningúno, que los ríos corren a la már, que arderán muchos montes, que avrá grande mortandád de todo género de ganados, y en todas las ciudádas avrá unos mónſtruos que echarán llamas por la boca, y los hombres que no comiéron lo que éſtos vomitáren, morirán.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: And that the moone euery night doth appeere after hir old faſhion, that thei. Starres receiue their light of the ſunne. ſtarres if it were not for the ſunne, ſhould haue no light, that all riuers run into the ſea, that manieAs mount AEtna in Sicilie and others which continually caſt out fire and brimstone, &c. mountains ſhall burne, that there ſhall be a great ſlaughter of al kind ofFor mans meate to eate. cattell, and in all cities there ſhall be monſters which ſhall casti. Ouens wherin they bake breade. out fire at the mouth, and thoſe men which ſhal not eat that which theſe monſters ſhall vomite, they die.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Vala me Dios, yo pienſo que todo éſſo es mentíra.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: God helpe me, I thinke al this to be a lie.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Los Pronóſticos dízen, que el ſol y la luna faltarán, antes que todas éſſas coſas fálten.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: The Prognostications ſay that the ſun and the moone ſhall faile of their courſes rather then theſe thinges to faile.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Deſſa manéra, todos los hómbres morirán, porque quien ha de comér lo que vomitáren los monſtruos?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: By this meanes, all men ſhall die, for who can eat that which theſe monſters ſhall vomit?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Pues as tu comído vn aſno entéro, y no comerás de aquello?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Why hast thou ſwallowed downe anMade a gull. aſſe whole, and wilt not eat of it?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Si yo ſoy aſno, vos ſoys mula.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: If I be an aſſe thou art a mule.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Xo que te eſtriégo que lárgas le naciéron a v.m.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Hoc, a voice that carters vſe to make their horſes ſtand ſtill. Ho I do rub thee, for they are ſprung vp veriei. Long eares, calling him thereby aſſe. long to your worſhip.Calling of him by this a Iewe, which for the most part haue long noſes.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Tan lárgas como ſus narízes.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: So long as your noſe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Va a vér a tu tía Hermáno?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Go you to ſee your aunt brother?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: No que ya ví a tu madre, en la pellejería.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p:
Not ſo, for I ſaw thy mother in a brothel
houſe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Ha & Ralláme, then it is Grate me, and Harra allá then it is haight that way as one ſaieth to an aſſe.Harrallame eſſe quéſo.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Grate me this cheeſe.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Harralláme eſſe aſno.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Haight that way this aſſe.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Toda la vida has de comér ſin pláto?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: What art thou to eate thy meate all thy life without a platter?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Toda la vída has de comér tu cabrón?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Art thou to eate all thy life of goates fleſh?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: O Dios te bendíga la bella alimaña.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: O God bleſſe thee faire beast.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: O Dios te deſpache déſte mundo para el otro.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: O God rid thee out of this world into the other.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Dízen me que es v.m. gran comedór de huévos aſſádos.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: They tell me that you are a great eater of hard egges.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Tambien me han dícho a mi que v. m. come muy bien bacaláo.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Alſo they tell mee that you eate verie well poore Iohn.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: O ſi todos los áſnos truxéran albárdas, que buen ofício era el, de los albardéros.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: O if all aſſes ſhould carrie pack-ſaddles, what a good trade ſhould the pack-ſadler haue.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Si eſſo fuere anſi, vna mas tenía de coſta vueſtro ámo cada més.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: If it were ſo, your maſter ſhoulde bee at the charge of one packe-ſaddle more euery moneth.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Si del nécio ſe uviéra de pagár alcavála, quanto ganáran los Alcavaléros con v.m?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: If there ſhoulde bee ſubſidie gathered vp of euery foole, how much would the gatherers of the ſubſidies put into their purſe with your worſhip?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: En éſſa hazienda nádie podria tratár, porque dizque es património de v.m.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: In this goods none could meddle, bicauſe it is ſaide it is your patrimonie.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Todo es de vn pedáço v.m.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: All your worſhip is one peece.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Si, peró es de aguijón para picár a v.m.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Yea, but it is a pricke to ſpurre you forewarde.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Mas no créo que es ſino de atun de yjáda.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: But I beleeue it not but that is a peece of a Tunnie fiſh of the bellie ſide.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Si de atun fuéra ya v.m. uviéra arremetido a la pieça, como el aſno a la ceváda.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: If it were of a Tunnie fiſh you had ſet vpon a peece of it as greedilie as an aſſe on the prouender.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Paréce me hermáno que aunque tu entráſte en la corte, nunca la corte entró en ti.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: It ſeemes to me brother, although thou entredſt into the court, the court neuer entred vnto thee.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: En la de los puércos concédo, porque como es tu juridición, no ſe háze en ella, ſino lo que tu ordénas.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: In that of hogs I graunt, for as it is thy iuriſdiction, there is nothing done therein but that thou doeſt appoint.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Por vída tuya que me digas, quantos curſos tienes de nécio.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I pray thee tell me how many degrees of a foole hast thou?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Los miſmos que vos de majadéro.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: As many as thou hast of a ioulthead.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yo pienſo, que éras ya doctór en ynſenſato.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I thinke thou wast doctor in ſenceleſſenes.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Y vos eſtáys graduádo por cavalleríza.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: And you taken degree in the ſtable.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: A Dios hermáno, y roe bien éſſos grançónes.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Farewell brother, and gnaw well theſe huskes.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Y rumiád vos como buen cabrón eſótros.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: And brouſe you as a good he-goat theſe others.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Par diez, bueno te ha parado el amígo.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: By ten, thy friend hath brought thee to a good paſſe.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Amígo ſerá el de v'na taça de vino.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: He will rather prooue a friend to a cup of wine.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: E'ſte es de los que aconcejáva el óſſo, que hizieſſemos poco caſo.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: This is ſuch a friend that the beare counſelled that we ſhould make but little reckoning of.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Como es eſſe quento?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: How is that tale?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Quenta yſópo, que vna véz dos amígos ván camíno a pie, por vn monte, y ſalió a ellos vn óſſo, el vno echando mano a ſu eſpada, ſe quíſo defendér a ſi y a ſu compañéro, al qual díxo que hiziéſſe lo miſmo, para que ni el vno ni el ótro muriéſſen, el compañero que tenía mas cuenta con ſu ſalúd, que con el del ótro, a trevióſe ántes a ſus pies, que a ſus mános, y no curando del compañéro, dio a huýr a vn árbol álto que allí vido, y ſe ſubió en el, donde eſtuvo ſegúro del pelígro. El compañéro viſto que el ſolo no ſe podía defendérſe del óſſo, ſe dexó caér en tiérra haziéndo muéſtras de que eſtáva muerto, tenía el huélgo y no reſolláva miéntras el óſſo llegó y le olió todo, las narízes y la boca, y los oýdos, y penſando que eſtáva muérto, ſe fue de allí, ſin hazérle ningun daño. El que eſtáva en el árbol, víſto que el óſſo era ýdo, baxó del, y pregunto a ſu compañéro, que éra aquello que el oſſo le avía dicho al oýdo: El otro reſpondió, dezíame que con tan ruynes compañeros como vos, nunca hiziéſſe camíno otra vez.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Aeſope tels, that on a time two friendes trauelled a foote together, and going by a wood, a beare came out to them, the one laying hand on his ſword meant to defend himſelfe, and his companion whom he willed that he ſhould doe the like, that neither one of them nor the other might not miſcarrie; his companion which made more account of his owne ſafetie then his fellowes, was more bolde vpon his feete then vpon his hands, and not reſpecting his fellow, betooke himſelfe to fly to a high tree which there he ſawe, and climed vp the ſame, where he was ſafe from the danger. His companion ſeeing that alone he could not defend himſelfe from the beare, cast himſelfe downe on the ground, making ſhewes that he was dead, he held his breath, and did not once blowe while the beare came and ſmelt him round, his noſe and his mouth, and his eares, thinking he had been dead went his way, without doing him any harme. He that was in the tree, ſeeing that the beare was gone, came downe the tree, and asked his fellow what was that that the beare had told him in his eare: The other anſwered, he told me that with ſuch bad companions as your ſelfe I neuer ſhoulde trauell againe.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Reſpondió muy diſcretaménte, y ſi yo lo ſupiéra ántes, uviéra le contádo eſſe quénto a eſtotro mierda en palíllo, que pienſa que ſábe mas que Bártulo ni Baldo.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: He anſwered verie well, and if I had knowne it before, I would haue told this tale to this turd vpon a ſticke, which thinkes hee knowes more then Bartulus or Baldus.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
Por cierto el túvo demaſiada razón, amotejarte de nécio pues eſtuvíſte
tan torpe que no entendíſte ſus pronóſticos y adivinánças.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
Truely hee had to too much cauſe to ſcoffe at thee for a foole, ſeeing
thou wert ſo dull that thou vnderſtoodest not his prognostications and diuinings.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Pues tu entiéndes las mejór?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Doest thou then vnderſtand them better?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Yo entiendo las como el las díxo.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I vnderſtand them as he ſpake them?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Pues yo bien créo que entiéndo Romançe, y el en Romance habláva que no en algaravia.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But I beleeue well that I vnderſtand Spaniſh, and he ſpake in Spaniſh and not in the Moores toong.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Pues quieres vér como debáxo del ſayál ay al: y que aun que te habló en eſpañol, es algaravía de allende para ti.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: But wilt thou ſee, how vnder courſe attire is ſome wiſedome, & although he ſpake Spaniſh it is the Moores toong to thee.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Ya lo deſſéo vér como es.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I deſire to ſee how it is.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Pues lo priméro que díxo que el Turco ſe ha tornádo móro, es lo el de profeſſión y de ley, y ſuelo ſiempre: tódos síguen la ſeta de Mahóma. Que Venécia náda en água, es verdád que eſtá fundada en la már, que Ytália eſtá lléna de hómbres, tambien es verdád como Ynglatiérra lo eſtá, Tambien que en Fráncia, ay mas de cien mil hombres de guerra, quien no lo sábe que quando el Rey quiera, podrá ſacár della mas de dozientos mil.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: The first then that hee ſaide, that the Turke is become a Moore or an Infidell, he is ſo by his profeſſion and law, and alwaies hath beene: all follow the ſect of Mahomet. That Venice doth ſwim in water, it is true, for it is built in the ſea: that Italy is full of men, alſo it is true as England is: alſo that in France are more then a hundred thouſand men of armes, who knowes it not, that when the king will, hee may drawe out thereof more then two hundred thouſand.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Todo éſſo bien lo entiendo yo, peró lo de más, como ſe puede entendér, que el conde de Flandes aya dormído con la Réyna deſpaña y no ſe anda el mundo en guerras.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: All this I vnderſtand well, but the rest how is it to be vnderſtoode, that the earle of Flaunders hath lien with the Queene of Spain, and the world not to be vp in armes.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Pues bobo no sábes tu, que el conde de flandes y el rey deſpana es todo una própria perſona.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Why foole dost not know, that the earle of Flaunders and the king of Spaine is all one perſon.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Iuro a tal, que tiene razón, que no avía yo caýdo en ello.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I ſweare by ſuch a one, hee ſaith true that I did not light vpon.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
Pues lo demas que díze que el ſol es mayor que toda la tierra, es muy gran verdád, ſegun demonſtraciónes aſtrológicas, que yo con ſabér poco te las pudiéra dár a entendér, ſi uviéra lugár. Que la luna aparecerá cada noche de ſu manera, eſſo tu lo vées cada dia con ſus creſciéntes y menguantes, nunca eſtá una noche, como eſtúvo otra: pues que arderán muchos móntes, tambien es verdád, que ay en el mundo muchos
que lláman Bolcánes, como el de Sicília, que ſiempre eſtá ardiendo. Que morirá mucho ganado, quien lo ygnóra que lo han de matár los hombres para comér.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
But the reſt, which he ſaith, that the ſun is bigger then the whole earth, is very true, according to aſtrological demonstrations, which I in knowing but a little coulde eaſilie make thee vnderstand, if there were time and place, that the moone will appeere as it was wont, that thou ſeest continually with hir waxing and waning, ſhe is neuer one night as ſhe was the other night, then that many mountaines ſhall burne, alſo it is true, for there bee
many in the worlde, as mount Aetna in Sicilie, which alwaies burnes, &c. that there ſhall bee a great ſlaughter of cattell who is ignorant thereof, for men are to kill them for to eate them.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Todo eſſo entiendo bien, peró aquello de aquéllos mónſtruos, que echarán llamas por la boca, y que hémos de comér lo que ellos vomitáren, no puédo y penſár que ſéa.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: All this I vnderſtande well, but that of thoſe monſters, which ſhall cast out flames out of their mouthes, and that we ſhall eate of that they ſhall vomite, I cannot thinke what it maybe.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Eſſo es mas fácil que eſótro, porque aquellos monſtruos, ſon los hórnos ado ſe cueze el pan, que échan llámas, y por la boca vomítan el pán que comémos.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: This is more eaſie then the other, for thoſe monsters are ouens, where they bake bread which caſt out fire, and by the mouth of it, it vomiteth the bread which we eate.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Aora dígo que tiénes razón, y que yo eſtáva en bábia, y que puede vn nécio con vna necedád forjáda en ſu ymaginación dár en que entendér a cien ſábios.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Now I ſay you ſay true, and that I was in foolerie, and that a foole with his fooliſhnes framed in his owne imagination may giue to a hundred wiſe men matter to picke out.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Aſſi le a aconteció al poéta Oméro, que como con la vejéz eſtuvieſſe ciégo y ſe anduviéſſe paſſeando por la orilla de la már, y oyó hablár a ceirtos peſcádores, que en aquel punto ſe eſtávan eſpulgando, y come les preguntáſſe que péſca hazían, éllos entendiendo por los piójos, reſpondiéron los que tenémos buſcámos y los que no tenemos hallámos, pues como el buen Oméro no viéſſe lo que ellos hazían, y por eſta cauſa no entendiéſſe la Enígma, fue tanto lo que fatigó ſu ymaginación y entendimiénto, por entendér la y alcançár el ſecreto dello, que fue baſtante éſta peſadumbre a hazer le morír.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: So it happened to the Poet Homer, that as he was with age blinde and went walking by the ſea ſhoare, and heard certaine fiſhermen talking, that at that time were a lowſing themſelus, & as he asked them, what fiſh they caught, they vnderſtanding that he had meant their lice, they anſwered, thoſe that wei. Haue in their clothes, i. lice. haue, we ſeeke for, and thoſe that wei. Haue not in hand. haue not we find, but as the good Homer, could not ſee what they did, and for this cauſe could not vnderſtand the riddle, it did ſo greeue his vnderſtanding to obtaine the ſecret of this matter, which was a ſufficient greefe to cauſe his death.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: El lo hízo no como ſábio, ſino como muy gran nécio, en martarſe por lo, que no podía alcançar.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: He did that not as a wiſe man, but as a very great foole, in caſting awaie himſelfe for that he coulde not reach vnto.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Yo bien créo que no morirás tu deſſe acháque.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I well beleeue thou wouldſt not die for ſuch a matter.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p:
No hermáno, que no páre ya mi madre, y yo conténto me con lo que buenaménte y ſin mucho
trabájo puedo alcançár.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p:
No brother, for my mother is paſt childe bearing, and I content my ſelfe with that I may well and without
much labour reach vnto.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: ❀ Pues quien no es mas de otro, no meréce mas que ótro, y quien no ſáve no vále, y quien ruyn es en ſu villa, ruýn es en Sevílla, y quien adelante no míra atras ſe hálla.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: But hee that is not more then another doth deſerue no more then another, and hee that hath not knowledge, is of no woorth, and he that in his owne towne is vile, and is alſo bad and naught in Seuile, and he that lookes not before he leape may fall into the ditch.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Yo hermáno, quiero andár por do anda el buey, y aſentár el pie llano, no tomár de las cóſas mas de aquéllo que me diéron, y porque quiero del mundo gozár, quiero oy'r, y vér y callár.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Brother, I wil go where the oxe hath troden, and ſet downe my foote ſofte and faire, not to take more matters then that they ſhall giue mee, and bicauſe I will liue in reſt I will heare and ſee and hold my peace.

row.cell: Diálogo ſexto, que paſſó entre dos amígos Yngléſes y dos Eſpañóles, que ſe juntaron en la lónja de Lóndres, en el qual, ſe trátan muchas coſas curióſas, y de gúſto, ſon los Yngleſes Egídio y Guillérmo, los Eſpañoles Diego y Alónſo.

The ſixt Dialogue which paſſed between two friendes Engliſhmen, and two Spaniards, which met vpon the Exchange in London: wherein are handled many curious matters, and delightful: the Engliſh men are named Giles and William, the Spaniardes Iames and Alonſo.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: QVe hazéis Guillermo?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: WHat do you William?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Ya lo veis Exídio.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: You euen ſee Giles.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Como eſtáys tan oçióſo?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Why are you ſo idle?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: ❀ Quia nemo me conduxit.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Bicauſe no man hath hired me.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Pues yo os conbído aun ráto de buena converçaçión.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Then I inuite you for a while into good companie?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Adónde?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Veníd os comígo, no yréys adonde yo os lleváre?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Come with me, will you not go whither I ſhall leade you?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Si me lo dezís priméro, por que ýr hombre, ſin ſavér adonde, ſería neçedád.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: If you tell me first, for it were follie for a man to go hee knowes not whither.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Luego no hazéis confiánça de mi?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Do you not now truſt me?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Si hágo, mas no ſabéis que no todos los umóres ſon unos, y que podrá ſer, lo que a vos os da guſto, enfadár me a mi.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Yes I do truſt you, but do you not knowe, that all humours are not one, and it may be, that which likes you may very much diſpleaſe me.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Si, peró yo conózco ya'vueſtro umór, y me acomódo con el.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yea, but I know your humour, and I do applie my ſelfe vnto it.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Con todo éſſo, dezídme adonde me lleváys.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: But for all this, tell me whither you carie me.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Vámos a la lónja, adonde me eſtán eſperando dos amígos Eſpañóles, muy diſcretos, guſtaréis de ſu buena converſación.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Let vs goe to the Exchange where two Spanyards very diſcreete men my friends are tarrying for me, you ſhall haue a taste of their good conuerſation.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Háblan ynglés?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Speake they Engliſh?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Vn poquíto, peró pues vos entendéis bien el Eſpañol, y yo tanbien no ympórta.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: A very little, but ſeeing you vnderſtand well the Spaniſh and I alſo, it makes no matter.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Huelgo me de ýr, aunque no ſéa, mas de por aprendér algunas buenas fráſis Eſpañólas.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: I am glad to goe, though it be but to learne ſome good Spaniſh phraſes.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Eſſas ſé yo que las tiénen buenas, porque ſon de Tolédo donde es la príma de la lengua Eſpañóla.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Thoſe I knowe they haue and good ones, bicauſe they are of Toledo where is the prime of the Spaniſh toong.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Son por ventúra aquéllos, que ſe ándan alli paſſeándo.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: They are peraduenture thoſe which goe there walking.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Los própios, vámos allá, Dios guarde a vueſtas mercédes.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: The very ſame, let vs goe meete them, God ſaue your worſhips.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Y venga con vueſtas merçédes.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: And welcome in Gods name.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Paſſe adelante la converſación de que ſe tratáva aóra.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Proceede in that conference which paſſed betwixt you.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: No pareze ſino que la entendíſtes, que reſpondíſtes a élla ſin daros el pie.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: It ſeemes that you vnderstood it, that you made anſwere to it without giuingAs in plaies one takes the last word of anothers ſpeech, and by that knowes when to ſpeake. you the qu.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Tratávamos de las ſalutaciónes, que ſe úſan en Ynglatérra, y de las que ſe úſan in Eſpáña.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: We entreated of the ſalutations which are vſed in England, and of thoſe which are vſed in Spaine.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Quales ſon mejóres?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Which are better?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Cierto en eſto, adonde quiera, ay abúſos, quando dize el eſpañol Dios os guarde, en ora buéna eſtéys, Dios os de ſalúd, y el Yngles buénas tárdes y ótras ſemejantes yo apruévola por buena ſalutación.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Truely in that matter, there are abuſes on both parts, when the Spaniard ſaith God keepe you, a good houre haue you, God giue you health: and the Engliſhman Godden, or good euen, and the other like, I allow it for good ſalutation.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Pues el mundo la repruéva, y tienen por tóſcos a los que la úſan.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: But generally it is diſallowed, and they hold them rude that vſe it.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Y aun por eſſo ſe díze, que anda el mundo a el rebéz, y no ay mejór ſeñál de que ello es buéno, de vér que el mundo lo repruéba.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: And therefore it is ſaide, the world goes quite contrarie, and there is no better ſigne that it is good, then to ſee it diſallowed in the world.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: De las demas ſalutaciónes que os paréce?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: And of the other ſalutations what think you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: De las de mas dígo, que quando el Yngles pregúnta a el ótro, como eſtáys, dize una gran neçedád, y quando el Eſpañól dize béſo os las manos, dize una gran mentíra.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Of the reſt I ſaie, that when the Engliſhman doth aske the other, howThe Spaniard alloweth not how do you, but how doth your worſhip or masterſhip. he doth, he vtters his owne ſimplicitie, and when the Spaniard ſaith, I kiſſe your handes, hee telleth a great lie.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Meneſtér es que déys razón, de vueſtra nueva opinión.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: You muſt giue a reaſon of your newe opinion.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Aóra dezíme por vuéſtra vída, no os pareçe neçedad a el que vos veys bueno preguntár le como eſtá?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Now tell me I pray you, doth it not ſeeme vnto you a ſimplicitie, to aske a man whom you ſee well, how he doth?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Tenéys razón, peró podría tenér algun mal ſecréto que no ſe le eche de vér.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: You ſaie well, but he may haue ſome inward griefe, which appeereth not outwardely.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Eſtónçes que remedáis vos, con preguntár le como eſtá, No ſería mejor, rogár a Diós, que le de ſalúd, como haze el ótro.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Then what remedie do you giue him in asking him how he doth, were it not better to pray to God to ſend him helth as the other doth.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Aóra dezíd lo de el Eſpañól.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Now tell that of the Spaniard.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: El Eſpañól dígo, que dizé mas mentiras entre año en eſte cáſo, que reáles da por Dios, porque dezir a el que encuéntra, v • ſo las mános a v. m. ſi habla de preſente, bien vémos, que miente, pues no ſe las beſa, ſi de futuro tanbien porque bien ſabemos, que quando el otro quiſiéſſe dar ſe las por muy amígo que fueſſe no ſe las querría el veſar.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The Spaniard I ſay in this caſe telleth more lies within the yeere, then he giues ſixpences for God ſake, for to ſay to one, that he meeteth I kiſſe the handes of your worſhip, if he ſpeake of the time preſent, we well ſee that he lieth ſeeing he doth not kiſſe them: if of the time to come, in like manner; for we well know when the other would giue him his hands to kiſſe, if he were neuer ſo great a friend, yet he would not kiſſe them.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Si peró paréçe que es vna manera de reconoſimiénto de ſuperioridád a el que díze.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Yea but it ſeemeth that it is a manner of acknowledging of ſuperioritie to him, to whom it is ſpoken.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Aſsí es, peró éſſe reconoſimiénto no éſta mas que en la lengua por ❀ que el refran dize, manos béza hombre que querría vér cortádas.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: So it is, but this acknowledging is no more, but in the toong: for the prouerbe ſaith, A man kiſſeth thoſe hands that he would ſee cut off.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yo os dire lo que ſubcedió al propóſito, a vn cavalléro viéjo eſpañól, con otro móço y fue, que como el moço por buena criánça, le dixo a el viejo ſuplíco a v.m. me de las mános, que ſe las quiero beſar el viéjo confiádo en ſu ançianía, las alargó para que ſe las beſaſſe, el otro ya arrepentído ſe las aſió con las ſuy as y con muy buen donáire le díxo ſenór yo y v. m. a otros dos.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I will tell you that which happened fit for this matter, to an auncient gentleman, a Spaniard, with another yoong man; and it was, as the yoong man for manners ſake ſaide to the old man, I entreate your worſhip that you will giue me your hands, for I will kiſſe them: the olde man preſuming vpon his yeeres, put them out that he might kiſſe them, the other repenting, tooke him fast by the hands with his owne hands, and with very good pleaſantnes, ſaid vnto him, Sir, I and your worſhip against other two.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: El moço andúvo diſcréto en hazér lo ansí, y el viéjo néçio, porque bien ſavémos, que palábras de buena criánça no oblígan.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: The yoong man was wiſe in ſo doing, and the olde man ſimple, for well wee knowe that wordes of compliment binde not.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Anſi es verdád, que eſſa çerimónia de beſár la mano, ſolo la deve el vaſállo a el ſeñor.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: It is true, this ceremonie of kiſſing the hand onely the vaſſall oweth vnto his Lord.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
E'ſſa ſola ſálua guarda tiene nueſtra
coſtumbre que con dezír, béſo a v.m. las mános, paréçe que es dezír, reconoſco a v. m. por mi Señór, y yo por vueſtro vaſállo.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
This ſafegard hath our custome, that
with ſaying, I kiſſe the hands of your worſhip, it ſeemes it is to ſaie, I acknowledge your worſhip for my lord, and my ſelfe for your vaſſall.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Y que os paréçe de éſta coſtumbre, que tenémos en ynglatérra de asír nos las manos vnos otros?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: And what is your opinion of this cuſtome, which wee haue in England to ſhake hands one with another?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Dos manos asídas, ſiempre fue símbolo de amiſtád, peró dár los tirónes, que aqui ſe dán vno a ótro, tengo lo por poca gravedád, y no ſé ſi diga por liviandád.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Two handes faſtened togither, alwaies hath beene a token of friendſhip, but to ſhake and plucke them, as here they do one to another, I hold it for ſmall grauitie, and I knowe not whether I may call it lightnes.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Antes paréçe que aquello es por mas confirmación de la amiſtád.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Rather it ſeemeth that it is for the greater confirmation of friendſhip.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: E'ſſa confirmación ha de ſer con óbras, y no con ademánes ni tirónes, quanto mas que deve avér muchos que con la máno asída y tirando, le deven de eſtár con el coraçón matando le.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: This confirmation ought to bee with workes, and not with geſtures, nor ſhaking of the hands, and ſo much the rather, bicauſe there are many which with hand in hand ſhake hands, and in hart would kill each other.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Que dizís de la otra de beſár los hombres a las mugéres publicamente.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: What ſay you of that cuſtome of kiſſing between men and women and that openly?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Eſſa coſtúmbre túvo ſu princípio en Róma, en el tiempo que ella floreçia, aunque ſe ynventó a diferente propóſito de el que aóra ſe úſa.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: This cuſtome firſt began in Rome, in the time it moſt flouriſhed, although it were inuented for a different purpoſe, then it is now vſed.

sp.speaker: G.
