sp.p: A que fin la ynbentáron?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: For what purpoſe was it inuented?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Los Romanos aboreçían tanto el víno en las mugéres, que tenián ley, en que condenáva a muérte ala que lo bevía, y porque no lo pudieſſen hazer aſcōdidamente, tenian liçénçia ſus parientes de beſár la, para que por el olfáto conoçieſſen, ſi lo avía bevido.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The Romanes did ſo much deteſt wine in women, that they had a law, in which they did condemne to death that woman which did drinke wine, and becauſe they might not drinke it without being knowen, their kinsfolkes had leaue to kiſſe the women, that they might knowe by their breath whether they had dronke wine or no.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Si aóra ſe vbieſſen de matár todas las que lo beven, yo veo que quedáramos ſin mugéres,

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: If nowe they ſhould kill all thoſe women which drinke wine, I ſee we ſhould be quite without women.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: No créo, que fuera muy gran pérdida, ſegun nos ſon cauſa de males.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I beleeue that it were not any great loſſe, ſeeing they are cauſe of many euils vnto vs.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
Yo para mi tengo, que la mayor cauſa de la deſoluçion en algunas mugeres de Ynglaterra es eſta coſtumbre de beſallos en publico, por que con éſto pierden
la verguença y a el tocamiénto del béſo, les entra vn veneno que las ynficióna.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p:
I holde that the greateſt cauſe of diſſolutenes in ſome women in England is this custome of kiſſing publikely, for that by this meanes they
loſe their ſhamefaſtnes, and at the very touch of the kiſſe, there entreth into them a poiſon which doth infect them.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Antes que ſe yntroduxéſſe éſta coſtumbre en Roma, cuenta Tito Lívio, que deſterráron de ella a vn ſenadór, perſona de mucha quénta, ſólo por que beſó a ſu mugér delante de vna híja ſúya

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Before this custome was brought into Rome, Titus Liuius telleth that they baniſhed out of the citie a ſenator, a perſon of great account, onely bicauſe he kiſſed his wife before one of his owne daughters.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: De vn eſtrémo viniéron a dár en otro eſtrémo.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: They fell from one extremitie into another.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: En Eſpaña no ſe vſa beſár los hombres a las mugéres?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: In Spaine do not men vſe to kiſſe women?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Si béſan los marídos a ſus mugéres, y eſto allá detrás de ſiete paredes, donde aun la luz no los puéda vér.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Yes the husbands kiſſe their wiues, but as if it were behinde ſeuen wals, where the very light cannot ſee them.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Es por que los Eſpañóles ſon demaſidaménte celozos.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: It is becauſe the Spaniards are too iealous.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, ſi no, per que ſómos tan trabieſſos, que no hémos meneſtér éſſe apetito, para hazér mil malos recaudos que ſería ſi tubieſſemos eſſe Ocaçión.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No not ſo, but becauſe we are ſo wanton, that we neede nothing to helpe our appetite, to make a thouſand ill matches which would fall out if we ſhould haue this occaſion.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yo créo, que antes cauſaría haſtío, y no andarían los hombres, tan golóſos, por que vedamiento es cauſa del apetito.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I do rather beleeue, that it would cauſe ſatiètie, and that men would not ſeeke it ſo greedily, becauſe forbidding is cauſe of deſire.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No es fuego el de la concupisçiénçia, que ſe ahóga por echarle mucha materia, antes es como la y dropesía, que mientras mas el enfermo béue mas ſed tiéne.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The fire of concupiſcence, is not ſuch as is extinguiſhed by caſting on much matter, but like the dropſie, that the more the ſicke perſon drinketh the more thirst ſtill he hath.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Eſpecialmente entre los Eſpañóles que por ſér de complexión coléricos, eſtá Venus en ſu punto.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Eſpecially among Spaniards, which are of a cholerick complexion, Venus is in her full force.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yo entiéndo éſſo al contrário, por que Venus conſiſte mas en vmedád que en calór, por lo qual entiendo que mas aptos ſon para ſemejante exercíçio los v'medos de complexión, que los coléricos que con de ſu naturaléza ſécos.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I take that quite contrarie, becauſe Venus cōſiſteth more in moiſture then in heat, whereby it ſeemes to me that the moist of complexion are more apt to ſuch matters, then the cholericke which are by nature drie.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Si peró la humidád ſin calor, ſeriá como la tiérra ſin el ſol, que no es ſufiçiénte de míſma a produzír coſa algúna.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea but moisture without heate, would be as the earth without the ſunne, which is not ſufficient of it ſelfe to bring foorth any thing.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Por éſſe, los poetas, caſáron a Venus con Bulcáno Dios pe el fuégo.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: For this cauſe the Poets married Venus with Vulcan God of fire.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p:
Mas Bulcáno ni Venus ſin Ceres y
Baco no valen vn Cáco, a fruit in the Indies or a ſmall peece of money there. caco.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p:
But neither Venus nor Vulcan, without
Ceres and Bacchus are worth a cherrie ſtone.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Pues yo para mi tengo, que en las tierras mas frías, eſtá mas reconçentrádo el calór naturál, y por éſſo con mayór àptitúd, en los que biven en las tales regiónes.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: But I for my part thinke, that in countries most cold, the naturall heate is more vnited in his center, and therfore is there greater deſire in thoſe that liue in thoſe countries.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No es eſſe calór reconçentrádo que eſtá enel coraçon el que es cauſa de eſte fuégo, ſino el que eſtá en la ſangre y partes exterióres.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is not that heate, which is ſetled about the hart, which is the cauſe of this fire, but that which is in the blood and exteriour parts.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Si peró no me negaréis, que el calór de la ſangre no proçéde de el, de el hígado.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Yea but you will not denie, but that the heate of the blood doth proceede from the heate of the liuer.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Aſſi es verdád, peró no óbra éſte efécto en ſu orígen y fuente, ſi no quando ſe ha derramádo por las. venas, y como la virtúd eſparzída, es mas fláca que quando eſtá vñida, ſi quando lo eſta es acometído el calór de ſu contrário el frío, y éſto confuérça y. veheménçia vénſe y resfría de ſuerte que no puede obrár ni hazér ſu efecto.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is true, but it doth not worke this effect in the originall and fountaine, except when it hath ſpred it ſelfe by all the vaines, and as the vertue diſperſed is more feeble then when it is vnited; ſo when it is ſo, the heate is ſet vpon by his contrarie the colde, and this cold with force and vehemencie doth ouercome and coole in ſuch manner, that it cannot worke his effect.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Aſſi es, y la eſperiéncia de éſto ſe vée en los cabrónes, que es animál luxuriosíſſimo, y en llevándo le a tiérras frías, o no puede bivír, o pierde mucho de ſu poténcia.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: So it is, and the experience of this is ſeene in great hee-goats, which is a most luxurious beaſt, and in carrying him to cold countries, either he cannot liue, or he loſeth much of his naturall ſtrength.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Los Faunos o ſemicápras, que los antiguos llamávan médios dióſes cuentan los autóres, y poetas, que éran en eſtrémo luxurióſos.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: The Faunes or halfe goates which the auncient writers called halfe gods, authors and poets tell that they were woonderfully luxurious.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Es verdád, que úvo o ay táles hombres en en mundo llamados faunos?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Is it true, that there were and are ſuch men the world called Faunes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
En la vida de Sant Páblo primér hermitaño ſe quenta, que en aquel deſiérto donde el hazía ſu penitençia, la hazía tanbien ſanto Antonio, el qual como por rebelacion ſupiéſſe como eſtáva allí cérca ſan Pablo, le fue aviçitár y en el camíno encontro con uno, el qual de la çinta para arriba, tenía forma perfecta de hombre, ſalvo que la cabeça tenia lléna de
corneçuélos pequéños, y de médio para abajo éra cabrón con muy largas vedíjas, y pies de lo míſmo.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
In the life of ſaint Paull the first Hermit, they ſay, that in that deſart where he made his repentance, Saint Anthonie likewiſe made his, who by reuelation knowing he was neere Saint Paull, went to viſit him, and in the way met with one, which from the girdle vpward had the perfect forme of a man, except that he had his head full of little hornes, & from
the middle downeward he was a he-goate with very long ſhagge haire, and feete of the ſame.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Hablava alguna coſa?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Spake he any thing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Si que el ſancto le habló, y le preguntó quien éra y el en un lenguáje muy bárvaro, pero tal que el ſancto le púdo entendér, le reſpondió, que era vno de los avitadóres de aquél deſiérto, a quien la çiega gentilidád adoráva por dióſes, peró que éran criatúras mortáles, y díxo mas a el ſanto, que ſu grey y génte le enbiáva a el por embaxador a rogar le a el Sancto, que róga ſe por todos a el comun Dios de todas las gentes, que bien ſavían que avia baxádo de el çielo y hecho ſe hombre por redimír a los hombres, y con eſto ſe fue por aquel deſiérto, con tanta ligeréza que en muy breve eſpáçio, le perdió de víſta el ſancto.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea for Saint Anthonie ſpake vnto him, and asked him who he was, and he in a language verie barbarous, yet notwithſtanding ſuch a language that the holy man could vnderſtand, he anſwered him, that he was one of the inhabitants of that deſert, whom the blinde Gentiles worſhipped for Gods, but that they were mortall creatures, and ſaide moreouer to the Saint, that his people & nation ſent him to him for an ambaſſador to entreat the holy mā, that he ſhould pray for all of them, to the common God of all nations, for wel they knew, that he was come down from heauen, and being made man to redeeme mankinde, and herewithall he went thorow the deſert with ſuch ſwiftnes, that in ſhort ſpace the holy man lost the ſight of him.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yo he leýdo tanbien, que a el emperadór Conſtantíno magno, le traxéron de eſſos deſiértos, otro bíbo, y lo eſtúbo muchos dias, y deſpues de muérto ſaládo, le traxéron por muchas partes de el mundo, para que todos le biéſſen.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Alſo haue I read, that they brought to the Emperour Constantine the great, out of theſe deſerts, another aliue, & there he was many daies, and afterward being dead and ſalted, they carried him thorow many parts of the world, that all men might ſee him.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Bolviéndo a nueſtra primera plática, que os pareçe de eſta ciudád de Londres?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Turning to our first ſpeech, what do you thinke of the citie of London?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: A mi me paréçe, en verano tienda, y en inviérno contienda.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It ſeemes to me in ſommer a ſhop, and in winter a contention.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Como ſe entiende éſſo?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: How is this to be vnderſtood?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Digo que paréçe, en veráno tienda, por que en aquel tiempo, todos los Señóres, cavalléros, y hidálgos, ſe ſalen fuera de ella, y ſe ván a ſus aldéas a paſſár el veráno, quedando en ella ſolos los oficiáles con ſus tiéndas abiértas.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſay it ſeemes in ſommer a ſhop, for that in that time, all the noble men, knights, and gentlemen, do goe out of the citie, and they goe to countrey villages to paſſe ouer the ſommer, onely artificers remaining in it, with their ſhops open.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Y por que lo de mas?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: And why the other?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
En ynviérno ſon los términos y, como acúden de todo el réyno a
élla a ſus pléitos eſtá, hecha toda contiénda o pléito, peró vltra de eſto es vna de las mejores ciudádes de elmundo a lo que yo en tiendo.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
In winter are the termes, and out of euerie place of the kingdom, they come
to it to their pleadings, and ſo it is made nothing but contention and wrangling in lawe, but beſides this it is one of the beſt cities in the worlde as farre as I perceiue.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Que dezís de toda la tierra en generál?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: What ſay you of the whole land in generall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Que es fertilíſſima y abundante, de todas las coſas que ella prodúze, eſpeçíal de ganádos, déven de ſer los mas grueſſos y mejóres de el mundo.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That it is most fruitfull, and abounding of all things, which it doth bring foorth, eſpecially flockes of ſheepe, which are the greatest and beſt of the worlde.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Y tanbien de ſemíllas es muy fértil.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: And alſo of ſeedes it is very fertill.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Anſi es verdád, peró como no puede avér coſa perfecta en eſte mundo, ya que en eſſo es abundante, le fáltan otras coſas neçeſſárias, a la vida vmána, que ella por la frialdád de ſu sítio, no puede produzir, y anſi tiéne neçeçidád, de comunicatión con otros réinos.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is very true, but as there cannot be any thing perfect in this worlde, ſo although in this it abounds, yet other neceſſarie things are wanting in it, which are required to humane life, which thorow the coldnes of the ſcituation, it cannot bring foorth, and ſo it hath neede of commerce with other nations.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Que coſas ſon eſſas, que dezís que le fáltan, que yo créo que no ay coſa en el mundo, que en ella no ſe halle.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: What things are thoſe which you ſaie, that are wanting in it, for I beleeue that there is not anie thing in the world that in it is not found.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Es áſſi verdád, peró es comunicádo de otros réynos, que bien véys vos, que en ella no ſe cría óro ni pláta, no ſe coje vino, ni azéite, açúcar, ſéda, eſpeçiería, ni frútas de las regaládas, como ſon çídras, limónes, límas, naránjas, granádas, alméndras, y otros mil géneros de ellas, muy neçeſſarios para el regálo de las gentes, y como dígo de éſtas pocas coſas, pudiéra dezír de otras muchas que déxo.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is true, but it is brought from other countries, for well you ſee that in it, neither groweth gold nor ſiluer, nor wine, oyle, ſugar, ſilk, ſpice nor fruits of the fineſt ſorte, as are citrons, lymons, orenges, pomegranats, almonds, & a thouſand other kindes of them, verie neceſſarie for the dayntie feeding of men, & as I ſpake of theſe fewe things, I could ſay of many others which I leaue.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Si, peró te némos otras, que sírven en lugár de eſſas cóſas, y anſi no las echámos menos, como çervéza por víno, mantéca por azéite, y otras ſemejántes.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Yea but wee haue others, which ſerue in ſteed of theſe things, & ſo we want them not, as beere for wine, butter for oyle, & others the like.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Con todo éſſo, ſería inposíble podér paſſár éſte réyno ſin comunicaçión con otro, lo que no tiene Eſpáña, que ſola entre todaslas provínçias de el mundo, podría paſſár ſin comunicación con otra, por produzír, dentro de ſi
todas las coſas neceſſárias, a la vida vmána.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Notwithſtanding all this, it were impoſſible this kingdome could endure without commerce with others, which Spaine ſtandeth in no neede of, for that alone among all the countries in the world might endure without communicating with
any other countrey, bringing foorth within it ſelf all thoſe neceſſarie things for mans life.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Pues, bien os podré yo dezír v'na cóſa, que Eſpáña no prodúze.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: But well may I tell you one thing which Spaine affoords not.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Qual es?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Eſpeciería, que al fin lo trá eis de la ýndia.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Spice, which you fetch from the Indies.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Tenéys razón, que éſſa fóla le fálta a Eſpáña, peró, como vos dixíſtes, tanbien ſe cría en élla, con que ſe podria ſuplír éſſa fálta.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You ſay true, for Spaine onely wants this, but as you haue ſaid alſo, there growes in it that which may ſupply this want.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Que es?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: En lugár de pimiénta, ſe cría vna yérua que llamámos pimiénto, cuya ſimiénte es de tanta fuérça, y de el própio efécto que la pimiénta, que viene de yndias, en lugár de clávos, vſan múchos de los ajos, y ſi no fueſſe por vn mal olorzíllo que tienen, ſon mas ſabróſos que eſótros, de açafrán gran cantidad ſe coje en Eſpáña, genxibre de pocos dias aca, ſe a començádo a plantár en élla, y ſe da bien.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In ſteede of pepper there growes an herbe which we call pepper herbe, whoſe ſeede is of ſuch ſtrength, and of the very ſame effect the pepper is which comes from the Indies. In ſteede of cloues, many vſe garlicke, and if it were not for a little ill ſmell which it hath, they are more ſauorie then the other. Great quantitie of ſaffron is had in Spaine. Ginger not long ſince is begun to bee planted therein, and it proſpereth well.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: A loménos no me negaréis, ſer mas fértil tiérra en general Ynglaterra que Eſpaña.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: At least you will not denie me, England generally to be a more fertile countrie then Spaine.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Digo que es verdád, y lo conçédo, peró tanbien os ſe dezír, que de éſſa fertilidád, viene la floxedád en las cárnes, y mantenimiéntos de ella, que ſon de poco nutrimiénto y ſuſtancia, y éſta es la cáuſa, de que los yngléſes nos notáys a los Eſpañoles por miſerables en el comér, por que las carnes de Eſpáña, como de tierra mas eſtéril, ſon de tanto nutrimiénto que ſi comiéſſe de éllas vn hombre tanto como en ynglaterra come, ſin dúbda ninguna, reventaria.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ſay it is true, and I doe graunt it, but alſo I can tell you that of this fertilitie proceedes the faintneſſe of the fleſh there, and the ſubstance of it, which is of ſmall nouriſhment and ſustenance, and this is the cauſe why the Engliſh men doe marke the Spaniards for pinching in their diet, for that the fleſh of Spaine as of a countrie more barren, is of ſuch nouriſhment, that if a man ſhould eate of it ſo much as in England they eat, without doubt he ſhould burst.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Por éſſo, ay uno manéra de dezír, comun en Eſpaña, tu padre ❀ çenó carnéro aſsádo, y acoſtó ſe, y murió ſe pues, no preguntes, de que murió.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: For this cauſe there is a common ſaying in Spaine, thy father ſupped with mutton rosted, and went to bed and died, do not now aske whereof he died.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
En la própia Eſpáña tenémos la iſperiéncia de éſto que la Andaluzía que es tiérra mas fértil
que Estremadúra, las carnes de ella, no ſon con mucho de tanto nutrimiénto, ni tan buen ſavor, como eſtas otras.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
In Spain we haue the experience of this, that in Andeluzai which is a country more fertile thenA prouince in Spaine. Eſtremadura,
the fleſh is not by oddes of ſuch nouriſhment nor of ſo good taſte as that of Eſtremadura.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Tanbien ſe vée éſſo en los yngléſes, que van a Eſpáña, que dízen que no puéden comér tanta carne allá, como comían acá.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Alſo it may bee ſeene in Engliſhmen, which go into Spaine, which ſaie that they cannot eate ſo much fleſh there, as they did eate heere.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Dezíme a óra, que os paréce, de el trato de nueſtra génte?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Tell me now, what you thinke of the Engliſh manner?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Generalménte hablándo, toda la gente yngléſa, es benína, y amoróſa, afáble, alégre, y amígos de regozíjos, y fieſtas, agénos de toda melancolía, como a quellos, en quien predomína el humór ſanguino, peró fuera de éſto, he notádo en todos en generál tan ynſatiáble avarícia, que deſdóra tódas ſus virtudes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Speaking generally, al the Engliſh people are courteous and louing, affable, and merrie, and louers of ſportes and feaſtes, free from all melancholie, as thoſe in whome doth predominate the ſanguine complexion: but beſides this I haue noted in generall, ſuch an inſatiable couetouſnes, as doth deface all their vertues.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Y de las mugéres que dezís?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: And what ſay you of the women?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Las mugeres generalménte hablándo, piénſo que ſón las mas hermóſas de el mundo, por que tienen todas tres grácias particuláres, para ſer lo, que ſon en eſtrémo bláncas, coloradas, y rúbias, y la que con éſtas grácias que ſon generáles a todas, aciérta a tenér buenas faiciónes, es acabada en hermoſúra: peró tanbien os dígo con la miſma generalidád, que tienen tres faltas.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The women generally, I thinke they are the moſt faire of the world, for they haue all the three ſpeciall graces which make thē ſo, they are woonderfully white & red, & that with theſe graces which are generall to all, there happeneth for them to haue ſuch good fauour, whereby they are most beautifull: but alſo I tell you with the ſame generalitie, that they haue three faults.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Quales ſon por vida vueſtra?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: I pray you what are they?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No las quiſiéra dezír, por no caér, en deſgrácia con éllas.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I would not willingly tell them leaſt I fall into diſgrace with them.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Yo ſalgo por fiadór que no cairéis.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: I will be your ſuretie you ſhall not.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: ❀ Teneis razón, que quien nunca ſubió, no puede caer, peró las tres faltas ſon, pequeños ojos, grandes bócas, no buena tez en los roſtros, y de eſto es la cáuſa el áyre tan frío y ſutíl, que corre en eſtas partes, que ſe les cúrte y por eſto es buena la ynbinçión la, de las mas caríllas, aunque yo entiéndo que no deve de baſtár.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You ſay true, he that neuer gat vp, can neuer fall, but the three wants are little eies, great mouthes, and not very ſmooth skinne in the face, and heereof the cauſe is for that the aire is ſo colde and ſubtill in theſe parts, which doth tan them, and therefore maskes were well inuented, although as I perceiue they helpe not.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Vos lo avéys diſputádo muy bien, y yo os quédo muy aficionádo ſervidór, y aſſi os ſuplíco, que el tiempo que eſtubiéredes en eſta tiérra os ſirváis de mi.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: You haue diſputed very well, and I remaine your affectionate ſeruant, and ſo I entreat you that the time you are in this countrey you ſo vſe me.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yo os doy muchas grácias, por el ofreçimiénto, y quedo yo no ménos a vueſtro ſerviçio, y por que ſe va haziéndo tarde, nos vamos recojéndo alas poſádas que ya es óra.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I giue you many thankes, for your offer, and I remaine no leſſe at your ſeruice, and becauſe it waxeth late, let vs betake our ſelues to our lodgings, for it is time.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: Beſo a vueſtas merçédes las manos.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: I kiſſe your hands.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yo las de vuéſtas merçédes.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: And I yours.

row.cell: Diálogo ſéptimo, entre un ſargénto y un cavo de eſquadra, y un Soldado, en el qual ſe trata, de las coſas perteneciéntes a la milíçia, y de las calidádes que deve tenér un buen Soldado, con muchos dichos graçióſos y buenas quéntos.

The ſeuenth Dialogue betweene a Sergegeant of a band, and a corporall, and a Souldier, in which are handled matters pertaining to warfare, and the parts that a good ſoldier ought to haue, with many fine ſayings & good ſpeeches.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: A Donde camina ſeñór ſoldádo?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: WHither walke you ſoldier?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: O ſeñor Sargento házia la tabla, ſi v.m. no manda otra cóſa.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: O ſergeant towards the dicing place, if you command no other matter.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Lleva muchos dinéros que jugár?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Do you carry with you much money to play?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Mi paga enteríta como la reçebí, que no he oſádo gaſtár vn reál, por no quirár ſe lo a el juégo.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: My whole pay as I receiued it, for I durst not ſpende one ſixe pence thereof, least I ſhould take away ſo much from play.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Eſſo es de buenos cofrádes, antes falte para el cuerpo que para él juego.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: This is the part of good companions, let there be wanting for the body, rather then for play.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: A que féria puedo yo ýr, en que mas gane, pues aventúro con quatro ducados ganár quatro-cientos.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: To what faire may I goe, wherein I may gaine more, ſeeing I venture with fower duckates, to gaine fower hundred.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Y ſi el dado díze mal, allá ván roçín y mançánas.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: If the die turne ill, thereA horſe laden with apples paſſing a riuer was carried away, and ſo both lost. goes horſe and apples.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Señor o rico pijádo, o muerto des calabrádo.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Sir, either hangedrich, or dead with head broken.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Eſſa es la quénta de los perdídos.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: This is the reckoning of cast awaies.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Cuerpo de tal ſeñor, que hijos o mugér tengo yo que mantenér?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Bodie of me, what children or wife haue I to keepe?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Si pero ne fuera mejor veſtír ſe que jugár el dinero?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yea but were it not better to apparell your ſelfe, then to play away your money?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p:
Yo he hecho mi quenta, y he meneſtér camiſas, jubón, ſayo, calçones, médias, y çapátos, y ſonbréro, y en quatro ducados, no ay para todo, pues conprár vno nuévo,
y traér lo otro viéjo, no pareçe bien, quiero jugár, quiça ganaré para comprár lo todo.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p:
I haue reckoned with my ſelfe, I haue neede of ſhirts, doublet, caſſocke, breeches, ſtockings, ſhooes, & hat, and in fower ducats there is not for all this, for to buy one thing
new and weare another old, ſeemes not well, I will play, peraduenture I ſhall get ſo much to buy all new.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Y ſi los pierde, quedar ſe ha ſin lo vno y lo otro.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: If you looſe, you must go without one and the other.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Señor, préſo por mil, préſo por mil y quiniéntos, todo es eſtár preſo, diré eſtonçes deſnudo naçí, y deſnúdo me hallo y deſnudo moriré.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Sir, arrested for a thouſand, taken for a thouſand fiue hundred, all is but to be arrested, I will then ſaie I was borne naked, and naked I finde my ſelfe, and naked ſhall I die.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Digame, ſáve quando entramos de guárdia?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Tell me, do you knowe when we watch?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Eſta nóche le toca a la compañiá.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: This night it fals to the companie.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Con que armas ſirve con pica, o arcabúz?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: What armes ſerue you with, a pike or ſhot?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Con vn moſquéte de ſiete palmos.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: With a musket of ſeauen handfuls.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Pues como díze, que no ſacó mas que quatro ducadas tieniendo ſiete depaga.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: How then ſaide you, that you had but fower ducats, hauing ſeauen for your paie?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Vno me deſcontáron de pólvora y cuerda los contadores, otro he dado a mi camarada para la deſpenſa de eſta ſemána, y otro que ſe me quitó de losSuccors or lendings which they giue ſouldiers when there is no paie and when the paie comes they take it off. ſocorros.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: One ducate defalked for powder and match, the other haue I giuen to my comerade for the charges of this weeke, and the other was taken out for lendings.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: juſta eſtá la quenta.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The reckoning is very right.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Es como la de el trillo, cada piedra en ſu agujéro.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: It is euen as a threſhing floore, euerie ſtone in his hole.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Quantos ſon de camaráda?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: How many cabbin mates are you togither?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Tres y con migo quatro.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Three, and with me fower.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Tantos pies tiene vn gato.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: So many feete hath a cat.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: çinco con el rábo.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: He hath fiue with the taile.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Tienen buen aloxámiénto?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Haue all you good lodging?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Tal ſea la ſalud de el apoſentador que nos le dió.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I would to God ſuch were the health of the Furriel which gaue it vs.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Como no es bueno?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: How ſo, is it not good good?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Peór es vna çahurda de lechónes.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: A pigſtie is woorſe.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Tienen huéſpeda hermoſa?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Haue you a faire Hosteſſe?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Hermóſa ſeñór ſarjénto, yo pienſo que los diablos ſon ſerafines en ſu comparaçión.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Faire maſter Sergeant, I thinke the diuels are Seraphines in reſpect of her.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Bueno es el encareçimiénto, que talle tiene?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: You giue her good commendations, what handſomnes is in her?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p:
Ella es mas viéja que Metuſalen, mas arugada que vna páſa, mas ſúzia que vna moſca, mas ſeca, que vnpalo, diente y muela, como por la mano, la boca ſu-mída, como ojo de culo, los ojos el vno tuerto, y el otro que no ſe le ſacaran con vn garaváto finalmente, toda ella es vn
retráto de la ynbídia.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p:
She is more olde then Methuſalem, more wrinkled thē a dried grape, or raiſin, more filthie thenWhich goeth and ſucketh euerie filthy wound or carrion. a flie, more drie then a ſticke: teeth and chock teeth as in ones hand, the mouth ſunke in as the hole of the taile, the eies one quite out, and the other ſo ſunke into her head that it cannot be pluckt out with a hooke. In fine, all of
her togither is the very picture of Enuie.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Eſſa tal ſerá v'nico remédio contra luxúria.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: She muſt needes be the onely remedie againſt lust.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Pues es lo bueno que con todas eſtas gráçias ſe afeita y repíca.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: But this is the best of her, which with all theſe good graces is painted out and ſpoken of.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Y v.m. no le haze el amór?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: And do you not make loue to her?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Amór, o que boto a tal, no la acométa vn Tigre.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Loue, I ſweare by ſuch a one, a Tiger would not ſet vpon her.

sp.speaker: Sá.
sp.p: A'nde, quae para vn lava dientes no ſerá mala.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Goe foole ſhe is good enough to waſh ones mouth, and ſpet out againe.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Mas me los quiero traér ſúzios que no mal lavállos.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I had rather they ſhould bring my cloathes fowle then ill waſhed.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Mas yo créo, que es como dízen, ❀ quién díze mal de la yégua, eſſe la lléva.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: But I beleeue, it is as they ſay, he that diſpraiſeth the mare carrieth her away.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Par diez, no ſoy ſi no como la zórra que quando no púdo alcançár las v'bas, díxo vbas de parra, anſi como áſſi no las aviá gana.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: By this ten bones I am no otherwiſe then the foxe, that when he could not reach the grapes, ſaid grape of the vine, ſo euen ſo that he had no ſtomacke to eate them.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Aqui viene el cávo de eſquadra, veámos que nuevas tráe. de donde viéne ſeñor cávo de es eſquadra?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Here comes the corporall, let vs ſee what newes hee brings. From whence come you Corporall?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: De la bandéra.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: From the colours.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Queda alli el alférez?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Is the Ancient there?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No ſeñor, que eſtá en cáſa de el capitan.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: No ſir, he is at the captaines houſe.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: A el capitan y alférez déxo yo aóra en cáſa de el maeſtre de campo.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: The captaine and Enſigne I left euen now in the camp-masters houſe.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Que nuévas ay por alla?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: What newes there about?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Nuévas ciertas pocas, mentíras ynfinitas.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Certaine newes verie fewe, lies infinite many.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Que ſe dize aóra en el cuerpo deguardia?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: What ſay they now vpon the guarde?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Vnos dízen, que nos enbarcarémos para corrér la cóſta, otros que que darémos aquí de preçídio, otros que yrémos a Yrlanda, no ay quien lo entiénda.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: One ſaies, we ſhall embarke our ſelues to skowre the coast, others that we ſhall remaine heere in garriſon, others that we ſhall goe for Ireland, none can tell what.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Todo eſſo es adivinár, cada vno loque deſéa o le eſtá bien.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: All this is, euery one to geſſe at that which hee doth himſelfe deſire, or liketh well of.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Como dezia el otro capitán los ſoldados ſon profétas de el diáblo.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: As another captaine ſaide, Souldiers are prophets of the diuell.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
Y tenía razón, porque aſſi como el diablo no ſáve lo por venír, ſi no que lo conjetúra aſſi házen ellos: y entre mil conjectúras
que házen, alguna han de açertár.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
And he ſaid well, for as the diuell doth not know, that which is to come, but by coniecture, ſo do they: & among a thouſand coniectures which they
make, they are to hit vpon one.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Tanbien ſe ſuena que el rey de Eſpaña, árma para venír contra Ynglaterra.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: In like ſorte, the rumor goeth that the king of Spaine makes preparation to come againſt England.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Venga en óra buena, ſi tráe muchos dinéros que dexárnos.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Let him come, if he bring good ſtore of crownes to leaue vs.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Yo con vna cadéna de óro que valga cien libras me conténto.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I woulde content my ſelfe with a chaine of golde, that were woorth a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Pues afee que no las ſuelen vendér muy baratas los Eſpañóles.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: But in faith the Spaniards are not wont to ſell them very good cheape.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Y yo con vna onça de plomo la piénſo comprár.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: And I hope to buie one with an ounce of lead.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: E'ſſo es hazér quenta ſin la huéſpeda: y quiça yréis por lána, y bolveréis treſquiládo: que adonde las dan las tóman.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: That is to reckon without the Hoſteſſe, and peraduenture you will goe for wooll, and returne home ſhorne, for where men giue there they receiue.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Señór, ſi me matáren, tal dia hízo vn año, tanbien murió mi aguélo, ya eſtá oluidado a éſſo jugámos, oy por mi, mañana por ti, no tengo hijos que dexár huérfanos ni padre ni madre, ni perro que me ladre ❀ muera Marta y muera hárta.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Sir, if they kill me, that daie made vp iust a yeere, in like manner died my grandfather, and nowe is forgotten, at this we play, to daie for me, to morrow for thee, I haue no children to leaue orphanes, neither father, nor mother, nor dogge that barketh at mee,A man hauing a wife named Marta which he often beate for too much drinking, at last almoſt killing her ſhe ſaid, Muera Marta, y muera harta. let Marta die, yet let her die full.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Plegue a dios que quando llegue la ocaçión no ſe calçe vnas calças de vílla Diego.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: I pray God that when triall ſhall bee made, that you doe noti. Run away. put on the hoſe of the towne Diégo.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Señor tan buenos hombres ay por los pies como por las manos.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir there are as good men of their feet as of their hands.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Por ſer mis oficiáles, vuéſtras mercédes me pueden dezír eſſo, peró ſi otro me lo dixéra, matára me con el.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: In that you are my officers, you may ſay this vnto me, but if another ſhould ſay ſo, I would fight with him.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: No dezímos aquí, que lo hará, peró podriá aconteçér.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: We do not ſay heere, that you would doe ſo, but it might happen.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Tanbien ſe podría caér el çielo y nos cogería debaxo.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: As well might El cielo, the skie. Alſo the tester of a bed. el Cielo fall, and then it would catch vs vnder.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Demanéra que tanta dificultád ay en huýr v.m. como en caérſe el cielo.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: So then it is as hard a matter for you to run away as for the skie to fall.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: El de la cama dize eſte ſoldádo.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: This ſoldier ſpeaketh of thei. Testerne of the bed. Cielo of his bed.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: No ſoy menór de edád que he meneſtér curadór, ſeñor cavo de eſquadra, yo ſabré reſponder por mi.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I am not in my nonage, that I neede one to care for me, master Corporall I ſhall know how to anſwere for my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Siempre oy dezír, que vna buena obra ſepaga con vna mala.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: I haue alwaies heard, that one good worke is requited with an euill.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: ❀ No ſabe v. m. que eſtá vna higa en Róma para el que da conſejo a quien no ſe le pide.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Do you not know, that there is a floute for him in Rome, that giues counſell to him that requires it not at his hands.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: No ſe enoje ſeñor ſoldádo que ſe hará viéjo antes de tiempo.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Be not angrie maſter ſoldier, for it wil make you old before your time.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: ❀ No puede ya ſér mas negro el cuérvo que ſus álas.

sp.speaker: So
sp.p: It cannot be woorſe then it is, or nothing can exceede the highest degree.The crow cannot be blacker then her feathers.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Señor cavo de eſquadra, vaya digale a el atambór que toque a recojer la guárdia.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Corporall goe and tell the drum that he ſound to ſet the watch.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Yo voy aguarde me aqui v.m.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: I goe, tarrie for me here.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Señór ſargento déxeme yr a jugár vn ráto antes que ſe meta la guárdia.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Sergeant, let me go plaie at dice a little before the watch be ſet.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Tanto le peſa eſſe dinero, que tal prieſſa tiene por echárlo de ſi.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: So troubleſome is his money to him, that he haſteth to throwe it from him.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Yo mas querría doblállo.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I woulde rather double it.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: ❀ No ſave como díze vn refrán, ſi quieres tenér dineros tenéllos.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Do you not knowe what the prouerbe ſaith, if you will haue money keepe it.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: De que sírve tenér pocos o Caeſar o náda.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: What good will a little do one? either an Emperour or nothing.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Vaya con Dios, y pare lo a buen punto.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Go in Gods name, and rest when you are well.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Dios me libre de vn azár.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: God keepe me from a hazard.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: ❀ Y ami de vellácos en quadrilla, y villá nos en gavílla, de moça adivína, y de vieja latína, de lodos a el caminár, y de larga enfermedád, de párrafo de legiſta, de ynfra de canoniſta, de eçetera de eſcrivano, y de réçipe de médico, de razón de diz que peró y ſi no, y de ſenténçia de conque.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: And me from knaues in my ſquadrō, & clownesi. Multitudes togither. in ſhocks together, from a maide that is a propheteſſe; and an old woman a latiniſt; from durt in iourneies; and from long ſicknes; from the paragraffe of the lawyer; from the infra of the Canonist; from the et cetera of the Scriuenour; from the recipe of the Phiſition; from that reaſon that ſaith, He ſaith that, but, if not; and from the ſentence of with which.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Ya toca la caja a recojér.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Now ſounds the drum to ſet the watch.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Vamos entre tanto a buſcár a el Sarjento mayór, para que me de el nombre.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: In the meane while let vs go ſeeke the Sergeant major, that he may giue me the worde.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: El eſtará en caſa de el generál.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: He will be at the generals houſe.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Vamos allá, que todo es camíno, es meneſtér que éſta noche aya muy buena guárdia.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Let vs go thither, for it is all in our waie, it is needfull to night that there be a good guard.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Por que ay alguna ſoſpecha?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Why, is there any ſuſpition of anie thing?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
Ay nuévas de enemigos, y aſſi es neçeſſário doblár las poſtas y reforçarlas, y ponér dos otres
çentinelas perdidas y que la ronda y contra ronda visíten amenúdo.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
There is newes of the enimie, and therfore needful to double the ſet men to watch, & to make them ſtrong,
and to put two or threeThoſe that lie cloſe vnder the enimie to heare that they ſaie and do. lost centinels, and that the round & counterround may go very thicke.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Pida v.m. a el ſargento mayór, que nos den leña harta, para que aya buena lumbre en el cuerpo de guárdia.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Require of the Sergeant maior, that hee giue vs woode enough, that there be a good fire vpon the body of the garde.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Anſi ſerá, y todas las armas eſtarán ❀ muy apunto que hombre aperçevído, médio combatído.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: So it ſhall be, and all the armes to be very readie, for a man well warned halfe armed.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Me neſtér ſerá dar a los ſoldados pólvora, cuérda, y balas.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: It will be needfull to giue to the ſouldiers powder, match, bullets.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Todo ſe les dará y órden a los coſelétes que no les falte piéça.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: All ſhall be giuen them, and order for the corflets that they want no piece.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Qual es la mejór árma de las que vſámos en la guerra?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Which is the beſt weapon, of thoſe wee vſe in warre?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: La pica es la réyna de las ármas.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The pike is the queene of weapons.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Poco valdrián las pícas, ſino ſe guar neſiéſſen con la arcabuçería, que dáña a el enemígo deſde a fuera.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Of little auaile were pikes, if they were not lined with ſhot, which hurteth the enimie a farre off.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Menos valdría la arcabuzería, ſi deſpues de dadala carga, no tuviéſſe adonde repararſe de la cavalleriá enemíga, y de todos los demás que le procuráren dañár.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Of leſſe auaile were the ſhot, after they had diſcharged, if they had no place to defend themſelues from the enimies horſemen, & all the reſt which ſhould endeuor to offend them.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Si, peró bien vemos que mayór daño ſe le haze a el enimigo con la arcabuzería, y moſquetería, que con las picas.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Yea, but we well ſee, that greater dammage is made to the enimie, by ſmall ſhot and musket, then with pikes.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Todo éſſe daño es poco en comparaçión de el que ſe reçibe a el deſbarate de vn eſquadrón o exérçito, el qual ſe ſiguiría luego con la cavallería, ſi las pícas que es vna murállafuerte, no ſe puſieſſen ala defenſa.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: All this dammage is little in compariſon of that is receiued at the ouerthrow of a ſquadron or armie, the which woulde followe ſtraight with the horſe, if the pikes, which is a ſtrong wall, did not put themſelues in defence thereof.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Por éſſo compáran a vn eſquadrón bien formado, a el cuerpo vmáno donde los braços, y piernas, que ſon los que óbran ſon los arcabuzéros y las picas que eſtán ſiempre firmes, y es de dó viene virtúd, a todas las partes de el eſquadrón, el cuerpo y coraçón.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Hereby they compare a ſquadron well in order, to a mans bodie, where the armes and legs which are thoſe that worke, as the ſhot and the pikes which ſtande alwaies firme, and from whence proceede force to all the parts of the ſquadron, to the bodie and hart.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Aſſi es, y aunſi miráis la forma de vn eſquadrón de los ordinários formado, con ſus mángas, hallaréis en el, la miſma forma de el cuerpo vmáno.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: So it is, and alſo if you marke well the faſhion of a ſquadron of the ordinarie ſquadrons made with his wings, you ſhall finde in it the very faſhion of a mans bodie.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Que partes ſe requiére que tenga vn buen ſoldádo.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: What parts are required in a good ſoldier?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Muchas, y muchos eſcriviéron de éſſa matéria, peró las mas neçeſſárias y ordinárias, yo las diré. El ſoldádo, quanto a lo primero, deue ſer muy honróſo, porque ſoldádo ſin hónra ſería de ningun provécho, pues ella es la eſpuela que le ha de hazér obrár lo, que no báſtan prémios, ni ruégos, ni amenázas de ſus oficiáles.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Many, and many haue written of this matter, but the most neceſſarie & ordinarie I will tell you. The ſoldier touching the first point, ought to be honorable, for a ſoldier without honor would profit little, becauſe it is the ſpur which driues him on to effect that, which rewards are not ſufficient to doe, nor intreaties, nor threatnings of his officers.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Por eſſo, deve el ſoldado traér, ſiempre eſcrita en la frénte aquella ❀ coplilla que díze, por la honra pon la vida, y pon las dos, honra y vida por tu Dios.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Therefore the ſoldier ſhould carrie alwaies written in his forehead this verſe, which ſaith, For thy honor hazard thy life, and hazard them both, honor and life for thy God.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Lo ſegundo deve ſér el ſoldado valiente no temeróſo ni covarde.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The ſecond, the ſoldier ought to be valiant, and not fearful nor coward.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: ❀ El ſoldado couarde mas propiaménte ſe podría llamár eſpantájo, al qual quando los páxaros le pierden una vez el miédo, ſe aſientan ençíma de el, o como el Rey de las ránas.

sp.speaker: Co
sp.p: A cowardly ſoldier may better be called, a thing made to feare away crowes, that when the birdes doe once cast off their feare of the ſame, they ſit on the top of it, or as the king of frogs.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Como es éſſo de el Rey de las ránas?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: How is that of the king of frogs?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p:
Dizen, que en tiempo de mari caſtáña, las ránas deſſeáron tenér Rey como todas las demas naçiones, y pidiéron a Iupiter que era Rey de los dióces que les diéſſe Rey el qual viéndo ſu neçedád quiſo burlár de ellas, y díxo les que para un dia ſeñaládo les daría Rey, ellas le eſperávan con grande alegría, y venído aquel diá, ſaliéron todas, de ſus caſas, muy compueſtas, como convenía para reçebír a ſu réy y puſiéron ſe en la ſuperfiçie de el água eſperando; en eſte tiempo Iupiter arrojó deſde el çielo, vn gran madéro, que dió con el, en la laguna donde, ellas eſtávā, tan grā golpe, y hízo tan gran ruído que ellas fuéron todas turbadas, y aſombradas, y unas por aquí, y otras por alli, cada una huyó a ſu caſa, ſin oſár llegár, a hazér a ſu rey el devído acatamiénto, ni ſalír fuera en muchos dias quedó ſe el madéro nadándo ençima de el agua, y ellas con tanto temór
de vér coſa tan grande, que ninguna oſáva ſalír fuera de ſu caſa, y alli morían de hambre, haſta que poco apoco fue ſaliéndo la mas esforçada, y ſiguiéndo la las demas, cada dia y'van perdiéndo mas el temór, y ſe y'van llegando çerca de ſu rey, viendo le a el tan manſo y que no ſe movía, ni les dezía mala palábra, al fin tanto continuáron y (como la mucha converſación es cauſa de menoſprécio) ſe llegáron a ſu rey y viendo todas lo que éra, ſaltáron ençíma de el, y començáron a cheriár y dar grandes riſádas, haziéndo burla de ſu Rey, y de ſu temor paſſádo bolviéron pues, a ynſiſtír a Iupiter que en todo cáſo les diéſſe Rey no tan mánſo, ſi no que fuéſſe juſticiéro, Iupiter viendo ſu neçia porfía les ymbió por Rey a la çigueña, la qual réyna haſta oy entre ellas, çebando ſe y comiendolas cada dia en pena de ſu loca petiçión, pues pudiendo bivír libres quiſiéron mas hazér ſe eſclávas y mas vn Rey cruél, que mánſo y benígno.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p:
They ſay, in olde time, when beastes could ſpeake, the frogs deſired to haue a king, as other nations had, and they requested Iupiter, which was king of the Gods, that he would giue them a king, which ſeeing their ſimplicitie, would needs mock them a little, and told them that by a day appointed, he would giue them a king: they waited for it, with great ioy, and the day being come, all of them came foorth out of their houſes, well attired, as was fit for the receiuing of a king, and put themſelues vpon the vpper part of the water waiting: then Iupiter caſteth downe from heauen a great blocke, which lighted in the lake where they were: it gaue ſuch a blow, and made ſuch a noiſe, that they were all troubled, & amaſed; ſome this way, others that way, euery one ranne home to his houſe without daring to come neere, to make their due reuerence to their king, nor to come foorth a doores in many daies. The beame remained
there ſwimming vpon the water, & they with ſuch feare, to ſee a thing ſo great, that none of them durſt once go out of his dores, & therin they died with hunger, vntill that by little and little, the most hardiest of them went out, and the reſt following, euery day they went more & more, looſing their fear, & they went neerer to their king ſeeing him ſo gentle, and that he mooued not, nor ſaid neuer an ill worde to them, in the end they cōtinued ſo long, and (as much familiaritie oftentimes breedes contempt) they approched to their king, & ſeeing all of thē what he was, they leaped vpon him, & they began to crook & to break out into great laughters, making a iest of their king, and of their own paſſed feare: they returned afterward to importune Iupiter, that by al meanes he woulde giue them a king, but not ſo ſtill and quiet, but that he ſhould be a iuſticer; Iupiter ſeeing their fooliſh importunitie, ſent the Stork to them for a king, the which raigneth til this day among thē, fatting himſelfe, and eating them vp euery day, as a puniſhment for their fonde requeſt, when they might haue liued at libertie they woulde make themſelues ſlaues, and rather ſet vp a cruell king, then a benigne and gentle.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: No ha eſtádo malo el quento, y mejór es la moralidád.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The tale hath not beene ill, yet better is the morall thereof.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Dexémos éſſo aóra, y prosíga v.m. adelánte con ſu plática de el buen ſoldádo.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Let vs leaue this, and goe forward with your ſpeech of the good ſouldier.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Lo tercero que ha de tenér ha de ſer gran ſufridór de travájos, y para eſto deve ſer de rézia complexion.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The third that he is to haue, is to be a great endurer of trauels, and for this he ſhould be of a ſtrong complexion.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Ya el que eſſo no tuviére, el diáblo ❀ le trúxo a la guérra, como dízen de el moço vergonçóſo, que el diablo le trájo a paláçio.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: And he that hath not this, the Diuell brought him to the warre, as it is ſaid he brought the bluſhfaced yong man to the court.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Deve tanbien ſer muy obediénte a ſus oficiáles, y que haga de buena gana y ſin moſtrár mal Roſtro lo que le ordenáren ſiendo de el ſervício de la Réyna.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: He ought alſo to be very obedient to his officers, and that he performe that obedience with a good will, & without ſhewing an ill countenance to that they ſhall ordaine, being for the Queenes ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
Quiten le a la milicia la obediénçia
en los ſoldados, y bolver ſe ha en confuſión Babilónica.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p:
Let them take away obedience in ſoldiers
in war, and it will turne to a Bablonicall confuſion.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Otras muchas particularidádes, ha de tenér el buen ſoldádo, que yo no quiero tratár aora, quien las qui ſiére vér, léa quatro o çinco tratádos que andan de ello en lengua Eſpañola vno de el capitán Martin de Eguilúz y otro de Eſcalánte otro de don Fernando de Cordua, y otro de don Bernardino de Mendóza, que alli lo verá bien pintádo.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The good ſoldier is to haue many other particulars, which I will not nowe handle, whoſoeuer will ſee them, let him reade fower or fiue treatiſes, which handle it in the Spaniſh toong, one of captaine Martin Eguiluz, another of Eſcalante, another of Don Fernando de Cordua, and another of Don Bernardin Mendoza, there may it bee ſeene well ſet out.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: A qui buelve nueſtro moſquetéro muy cabizbájo viéne, perdido deve de avér.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Here comes backe againe our muskettier, he comes hanging downe his head, it is likely he hath lost.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: A ſeñór ſoldádo vna palabra.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Ho Soldier a word with you.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Dexe me v.m. ſeñor Sarjento, baſta me mi mala ventura.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Let me alone Sergeant, it is enough that I haue ill lucke.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Que ha ſido, perdióſe toda el armada?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: What hath happened, is all the fleete lost?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: No topára yo aqui aóra con el velláco que eſte juego ynventó.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I would not meete now with that villaine that inuented this play.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Que le quería dezír?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: What would you ſay to him?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Reniego del diablo, ſi no le avía de hazér mas tajádas que púntos ſe han echádo en los dados des pues que el los ynventó.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I renounce the deuill if I woulde not giue him more ſlaſhes then hath ſet pricks on dice, ſince he inuented them.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: ❀ Eſſo me parece echár la culpa de el aſno a la aluárda quien le mandó a v.m. jugár?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: This ſeemes to me, to put the fault of the aſſe on the packeſaddle. Who commanded you to play?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: El Diablo que no duerme, y anda tras hazérme deſeſperar para llevárme.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: The diuell which ſleepes not, and followes after mee to driue me into deſpaire, that he might carrie me away.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Pues mire no le crea, ſino quando venga, diga le que por aora no puede y'r, que eſtá ocupado en ſerviçio de ſu mageſtad, que ſe buelva otro día, y ſi no quiſiére deshagale la horquílla en la cabéça.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Then marke what I ſay, do not beleeue him, but when he commeth tell him, that for this time you cannot goe, that you are imployed in her Maiesties ſeruice, that he come another day, and if he will not, clap your muſket ſtaffe on his pate.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Muy bueno va eſſo, eſtóy yo rabiándo y eſta ſe v.m. burlando de mi.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: This goes well, I ſtand raging, and you mocking.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Mire, yo le daré un buen remédio tomo dos onças de jaráve de paçiénçia, y quatro de unguénto de oluído y beualo todo, y con ello purgará éſſa malenconía y quedará luego buéno.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Behold, I will giue you a good remedie, Take two ounces of the ſirrupe of patience, and fower ounces of the oile of forgetfulneſſe, and drinke it off, and with this you ſhall purge this melancholy, and foorthwith you ſhall be well.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p:
Serán dos purgas una tras otra deſpues
de purgada la bolſa purgár el cuérpo.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p:
That will be two purges one after anoother,
after the purſe is purged to purge the bodie.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Pues nunca ha oydo dezír, que un clavo sáca otro, y una máno lava otra y entrambas la cara.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Haue you neuer heard, that one naile driueth out another, one hand waſheth another, and both of them the face.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Pues como ſe dió tan preſto fin ala triſte tragédia.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: But how made you ſuch a quicke ende of the ſad tragedie?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Yo les diré a vueſtras merçédes como fue, el me dió a parár a onze, paré le quatro reales, echóme un enquentro, y tirómelos.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I will tell you how it was, he chaunced me a eleuen, I ſet him two ſhillings, he cast and drew them.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Mal prinçipio.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: An ill beginning.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Antes ſuelen dezír, que es buen pronóſtico perdér la primer a mano.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Rather they are woont to ſay, it is a good ſigne to looſe the first hand.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: No ay regla tan generál que no tenga eçepçión.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: There is no rule ſo generall which hath not ſome exception.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Dióme a parar luego a doze, que es mi ſuerte, paréle ocho reáles, écho un azár, díxe repárolos, o torgó me el repáro, lançó el dádo, y echó otro azár.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: He chanced me forthwith twelue which is my chance, I ſet him fower ſhillings, he cast a hazard, I ſaid I ſet againe, he allowes of it, he throwes the dice, & caſts another hazard.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Pues pecadór, para que queríades mas de avér ganádo con quarenta otros quarenta, que mercadér ay que gane a çiento por çiento?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Why wretched ſinner, what would you more then to gaine with fortie other fortie, what marchant is there which doth gaine a hundred for a hundred?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Señor, yo no me contenté ſino quíſe arrancár las clavos de la meſa como dízen, y díxe ſiete y llevar, dixo me, digole, Relança y echa ſu ſuerte, y arrebuja cō todo ❀ ami dexóme del agalla, ſin blanca como el diablo ſe aparecio a ſan Benito.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I was not content but would pull in peeces the nailes of the table as they ſay, and I ſaide I ſet ſeuen times ſo much as he drew, he ſaid content, I ſaie content. He throwes againe the dice, & he drew vp al, and ſo he left meAs a fiſh. hanging on the gill, without a farthing, as the diuell appeared to Saint Benit.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: ❀ Siempre lo verá, que quien todo lo quiere todo lo pierde.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: You ſhall alwaies ſee, he that all coueteth, all looſeth.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: ❀Mas ſiempre deſpues de ydo el conéjo viene el conſejo.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: But after the ſteede ſtollen, ſhut the ſtable doore.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: ❀ Aóra bien quien érra y ſe enmiénda a Dios ſe encomienda.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Now he that erres and amends, to God himſelfe commends.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: La enmiénda ſerá empeñár el capotíllo, para bolvérme a eſquitár ſi puedo.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: The mends wil be to pawne the caſſock, to go again to quit my ſelfe if I can.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Eſſa no ſerá enmiénda ſino obſtinaçión.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: This will not be an amends but obstinacie.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: ❀ Aqui perdí vna agúja, aqui la tengo de hallár.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Heere lost I a needle, and heere hope I to finde it againe.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: No veis pecadór que ſe os cayó en la mar eſſa agúja, como la quereis hallár?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Do you not ſee, that this needle fell into the ſea, how will you now finde it?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Yo me tengo de yr a vna hechizéra, que me de vna ſóga de ahorcádo, que dízen que es buena para hazér ganár.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I am to go to a witch that ſhe may giue me a rope of a hanged man, which they ſay is good to make one winne.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: ❀ Caſtiga me mi madre y yo trómpoſe las.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: My mother doth chaſtice me, and I mocke and mewe at it.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: A ora ſeñór vamos por aóra a metér la guárdia, que deſpues ſe tratara de eſſo.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Now ſir, let vs go euen now to ſet the watch, for afterwards we will talke heereof.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Vaya a llamar ſus camarádas.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Go and call your Cameradoes.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Yo voy, béſo a vuéſtras merçedes las manos.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I go, I take my leaue of you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Yo tanbien quiero yr por mis armas.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: I will alſo go for my armes.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yo me voy a la vandéra, alli eſperaré.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I goe to the colours, there will I tarrie.
